CDq7JUHlKQ4LZmlqZu39Cw.text: I'm a huge fan of their spicy habanaero ramen! The resturant is quiet and feels very authentic. This is my new favorite place for ramen!

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Tatsu - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Love the habenero ramen!

ShRlv0VMay_Zs7xyFLWjNw.text: If you guys ever to eat real ramen, don't ever go here, the noodles don't cook well, like half cooked, I was kinda hungry when I went to place, it made me have no appetite after I tried it... My friend was like.. I would never go here again.! And don't order teriyaki which is totally terrible.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Tatsu - Las Vegas, NV, United States

VZFDUb6nTM7r1FISgCDr5Q.text: I wish they were open later!!!  Granted I shouldn't be eating so late in the first place to anger my stupid acid reflux, but as an industry person in Las Vegas, you sometimes just want late night ramen after a stressful shift. Am I right or am I right??        Now back to business..., LOVE this place!! Hands down the most beautifully flavored Tonkatsu broth in town in my humble opinion. That along with the fantastic service by the friendly wait staff makes it just that more perfect. For you gym rats on a carb loading day, have a small bowl of their curry rice with your ramen bowl and you..are...set!! Oh and the Chasu pork on that ramen? Packs a delicious delicate flavor that's truly accentuated by that amazing broth.  I could eat ramen everyday and I might have just found my new obsession...

XCms47syPk2gtVRe-Agq4g.text: Consistently fantastic! Been here probably once a week for the last year. Even at peak times I've never had to wait longer than 15 minutes for a table. Service is always warm and efficient. I haven't settled on a favorite ramen because I like them all. Most often I get the Tonkotsu Shoyu with spicy bean sprouts and an egg. It's rich, filling and delicious. Would recommend a hundred times over.

uyaOMcy9vBRVLiufT_kuxA.text: Smartly designed, low key authentic ramen joint. The food was filling and decently priced. Service was quick and courteous. The green tea cheesecake was definitely matcha, and delicious. I liked it a lot, definitely a established joint that can hold its own in the district.

ia_sZalS1bXWXlCOkAL7TQ.text: Ramen cravings in Vegas are never fully satisfied. Most of the ramen shops are comparable to one another - and by that, I mean either average or below average. The broths just don't cut it and the ingredients are always lacking. We tried Tatsu as an alternative to the jam-packed Sora and Monta and the results were about the same, except without the excessive wait times. The shoyu broth was nothing more than a glorified soy sauce base. The noodles and egg were decent enough, but the cuts of charsiu and lack of anything else was a let down. However, I would argue that there are a couple of benefits of getting your ramen fix at Tatsu. First, the ramen comes out pretty quick (almost too quick, which might explain some of the lacklusterness). Second, checking in on Yelp nets you a free soda. So, there you have it.

k4PXKU9_Ax-ZULXA5pDX3w.text: Awesome Tonkatsu and Shoyu ramen! Make sure to try the pork cutlet, gyoza and fried chicken! Fried garlic chips and seasoned egg are a must. The chasiu is flavorful but sometimes a little too fatty for my taste.  Reasonably priced, if you get shut out at Sora or Monta, this spot is the next logical choice if you are a ramenista!

IJz8afemO1MpxiQAm-30Kg.text: My ultimate favorite ramen place!! Came back from Japan and it felt like I was still there. From the ramen broth to the takoyaki..so authentic!! Then to finish the meal I got the yuzu sorbet and it topped it all off!! It had the right combo of sour and sweet!! Finally on top of it all the service and atmosphere. It was so low key and had cushions to sit on! And the girls..they are always nice and take care of your every need! I  ramen tatsu!!!!   P.s. Get the iced green tea. They always refill and let you take a to go cup!!

shiePv61zKF1N363vJKGfQ.text: We ordered Tonkatsu, Deluxe Bowl, and Karage.. and wish we couldve ordered many more. The pork is ok,  but the shoyu ramen is to die for! The price is very acceptable and portion is on the generous side.   RT is becoming a must stop for us whenever we are in town.

ZEdO1acxcksDX4vTKReWXQ.text: try their ramen, it is descent, the broth needs more flavors, place is cute, service is on par

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Tatsu - Las Vegas, NV, United States

URisxgT_mNbY9fqJiVhd8Q.text: A small restaurant in the heart of Chinatown - Ramen Tatsu is a great place to get your ramen/Japanese food fix.  I had the fried chicken (I know, I know - but I don't actually like Ramen) & a bowl of steamed rice, which was awesome!  My husband is a ramen-fanatic and he loved every bite.  He said it was a close second to the ramen he had in Tokyo!  Not only was the food great, the service was even better.  They were so super sweet to us and didn't rush us out when we were clearly finished eating.  If you are looking for a ramen spot in Chinatown - check out Ramen Tatsu!

bKrULDxUgIUfArwBVYeHdg.text: As a Japanese ramen fanatic, I'd have to say I was pretty disappointed with their tsukemen.   Broth wasn't thick and flavorful... If you cook and reduce the broth with the bones you would get more flavor, but it seems like they've just added more salt..  The noodles were broken and too hard. Tsukemen noodles should be soft, chewy and long. With the thickness of the broth and the texture of the noodles, the broth should really stick unto the noodle when consuming.  If you're ever in LA, go to Tsujita Annex and you'll know exactly what I'm talking about.   Just go with the miso ramen at this spot.. Or just go to LA.. Haha   Not one star because their Asahi was super refreshing :)

RBhBw6Eins8azPZer4gAFg.text: came into Las Vegas for a few days and had to get a ramen fix so we tried to hit up Monta...my second favorite ramen joint...unfortunately those guys were packed but fortunately this forced me to try Ramen Tatsu.   I got the tonkatsu spicy after the waitress told me this was her favorite and that they use habanero to make this dish spicy.  I was a bit turned off by the thin noodles that came as a default when I first saw the dish, but after eating a bit I was very impressed by the soup broth and the cha-su, which made the thin noodles a moot point.  I was only depressed by the egg, but after going to Monta a few hours later, it seems like the shops in LV don't know how to flavor the egg.  Anyways, I will be coming back for more.  I had Monta right afterwards and to be honest I think Ramen Tatsu might be better!!!

ZksAvx3Vu7bqVOj0ylsoSg.text: My general rule of thumb before heading out for ramen is to put on an old t-shirt. I'm a mess when I eat and usually end up with a couple spots of broth from the soup on some part of my shirt. My visit to Ramen Tatsu was no different. No matter how careful I am, I end up wearing some of my lunch. It was worth it, though, to try their tonkotsu ramen ($7.77). While it wasn't as creamy as I'd like -- the broth was thinner and more diluted -- the pork flavor was hearty. I'm not a fan of the really thin noodles, which were too al dente, but the tender pork with its rendered fat made up for it. The slivers of fat provided an excellent burst of flavor with each bite. Located in the same plaza as District One and Chada Thai, it can be tough to find parking during peak hours.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Tatsu - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Ramen Tatsu - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu ramen ($7.77)

LnfNEiAHmCIDUZnxRGqe0Q.text: I ordered the tsukemen and while the broth had a nice, interesting flavor, it was completely undermined by my ice cold noodles. After 2 minutes my broth became cold as well. Sort of a disappointing experience. If you learn from my mistake I think you might like it. The service was decent. I'll try it again next time I'm in town.

AQYIiQpaXay5Kj97VeMwqQ.text: Great Ramen, every time I come they are consistent with the flavor of their food.  Great service by the woman (don't know her name) but she has an amazing bubbly personality.  Nice happy hour menu.

9HSYUCnDPWZBc_Y2E_K1WQ.text: Wow!  I've been wanting to try a Ramen place for a while and my friends at work keep inviting me when they go.  I finally did and I was glad that I did!  I got the Curry Ramen Tatsu which was absolutely delicious and the write temperature.  HOT! But not too hot.  I quickly devoured the noodles I had and then ordered extra noodles for $1.50.  Totally worth it.    It was perfect.  Hit the spot juuuuuust right.  Not too much, not too little.    The women that was serving us was awesome and right on top of it.  The place was a little small, but don't let that deter you from an awesome Ramen Experience.  I can't wait to bring my wife here!  - Very Clean. - Excellent Service. - DELICOUS FOOD!

F6JN3TTBKy8vNh_J66Wsng.text: This is our favorite ramen stop in Vegas.  Hearty thick broth, no insane lines, and the waitress we always have couldn't be any more sweet or pleasant.  We just discovered a new fave drink, too.  Iced green tea - no sweetener but great green tea taste.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Tatsu - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Iced green tea - not sweet but ice strong green tea flavor.  Very refreshing.

F0NDOUH_uIzbkjt841h3mg.text: Authentic Japanese Ramen. Great service and great ramen. I want to say the best Ramen in Town!!!!!

eXPFpjald2lhB0a02bqMcA.text: So much better and shorter line than Monta Ramen.  We came here with a group of 4 on a Saturday night and got seated immediately.  Service was fast as well.  We all ordered the new ramen they had, the Spicy Tonkotsu Ramen, but I added garlic chips and egg.  Garlic chips were good but a little to potent for me.  You can't go wrong with adding egg to ramen.  We also order the takoyaki and karaage.  Karaage is a must try, though their portion is a little small, not bad for the price though, about $4.25.  Parking can be a problem since there are so many other stores within the plaza.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Tatsu - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Ate some of the karaage :)
Photo of Ramen Tatsu - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy Tonkatsu Ramen with added egg

vaYo3c90AujHbSgslLa-Og.text: After a not so pleasant experience at another ramen place, Ramen Tatsu was fantastic! The wait wasn't bad for a Friday night, and the service was very friendly. The ramen is amazing, and incredibly affordable! I got the miso ramen and it felt like the best thing I had ever eaten, especially with the cold weather. The ramen was piping hot and fresh. The only thing that bummed me out is that I asked for chili sauce, and the waitress told me to use the oil on the table, but then she brought chili sauce to the table next to mine. That threw me off a little. But still, I would absolutely recommend this location!

U_1r0J5ArML4oR-3nNUMPQ.text: Great and nearly authentic flavor of Japanese Ramen. The price are also pretty affordable. The taste reminds me of the real Japanese ramen. If you wanna find some traditional Japanese food rather than American style, this restaurant will be your choice

I2l1P_ABsp3UVotCdEw1rg.text: My FAVORITE ramen place in Vegas. I usually get the deluxe ramen because I like lots of toppings. Their habanero spice add in is delicious, and actually spicy! I've been going for years and it is consistently good.

525GKFYCoMWtD1d14BRMBw.text: My cousin and me were craving Ramen, so we decided to try out ramen from Ramen Tatsu. We both ordered the Tontaksu Shoyu Ramen, I ordered takoyaki while ny cousin ordered karagge(chicken). The broth was tasty.  The lady who took our order was nice.

RpfoynDVKiJ4tYT4XZr0PA.text: I really love this ramen place!!!! I wish it was bigger they have so many options and toppings to choose from and you can also make your own ramen!! And it's it expensive at all, i took my family here for dinner one time and enjoyed our meal!! Definitely a must try if you loveRamen!!

o8OrkG1gKvfn6Ju3x4iSmQ.text: The service was friendly and there was no wait for a table on a Thursday at 6pm but the ramen itself was just okay.   I feel like the ramen broth needed more flavor and I think it's odd that they don't have bamboo shoots in their ramen or to order on the side. I had also ordered some tonkatsu curry and the tonkatsu though tender was a little overfried.   If you're looking for a quick bite of ramen and don't have time to wait at some of the other ramen joints in Chinatown this might be the place to go.

Photo of Ramen Tatsu - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Katsu curry

T7U22BSDs3cTlYbY1xoWRg.text: Came here with two friends at around 11:30AM on a Friday when it opened. Place was fairly full, but we got a booth seat with no wait.   Service: (4 star) never nothing special but food came out quickly.  Tonkatsu shoyu ramen: (3.5 stars) above average but nothing special. Came with 2 pieces of chasu.  -Added a soft boiled egg to my ramen. Doesn't come with one but you can add it for a small extra fee.  Kaarage: (4.5 stars) crispy and fried well. Thought this was probably my favorite dish during the meal.  Deluxe (3.5 stars): this was the same as the tonkatsu shoyu but come with more chasu and an egg as well as the other condiments.   Would probably come here again but didn't blow me away.

AxYR2VJlSB3woPlvPtOGRw.text: I had spicy miso ramen and it was the best spicy flavor that i've ever tasted. I also had fried rice which was also great. I went there right before they close but the server was very friendly. I will definitely come back!!!

K2hIh4Npi6PtdsF_HXKR7A.text: Really good ramen! Had the spicy miso with an egg. Egg was cooked perfectly just the way I like it. I love the small atmosphere here. Will always be back for more!

E6N1HKdRJsXjER84kFEt-w.text: This place is super cute and has amazing service! Party of three with a baby and we were immediately seated and they brought my son a special cup and bowl. So cute! I got the kimchi as an appetizer and woooo was it super tangy! I got the veggie ramen and it was so good!! The broth was so good I barely added anything too it (just some chili oil lol). More importantly my son loved it! He loved the egg rolls and he even ate the kimchi! But he loved the noodles and the broth! I even took leftovers of the ramen and he ate it later that night! The only thing that sucked was it is cash only right now so either call ahead to double check or bring cash. Would definitely come back! And I love that they have veggie options!

sSOkKWMi9-wrYrNMq6VQCA.text: Ramen was alright. I wasn't in love. I tasted my husband's shoyu ramen and it had a strong porky taste which I hate. He thought it was ok.  I ordered the curry ramen. It was ok too. Left that dry mouth feeling afterwards.  We both thought this place was OK. Doubt we'll be back if we're in area though.

sGqgLD835_UqppAv4laJ2w.text: I knew something was weird when you can walk in without queuing up on a Friday night. Wife ordered the deluxe & I had the miso. That night after dinner, she almost died from food poison. I think something went very bad, could have been the pork broth. Be weary. Friday night dinner turned into Friday night restroom massacre. Something could have been left out. It's 4am and my stomach is still rumbling.  10am next day - my wife is still going..  Shame.  Shame.  Shame.

zjlOFrdQio7Zs_6AmHh2eg.text: Great Ramen place, 5 stars all day great service & food! Food came out quickly and hot.

zv3oB8TzsiT7Npoq1rJT_A.text: After my wife and I were disappointed during our last visit at Monta (Food was still good. Service sucked), we've been looking for a replacement spot and I can confidently say that this place fit the bill. The ramen was delicious and savory not to mention that they have all of the popular appetizers. They also have happy hour which is definitely a win if you're looking for a spot to decompress after work. We will definitely be coming back to this spot as regulars from now on. Hopefully it doesn't get too crowded.

2-nMr_8_jJpzziguvd8wkA.text: Their ramen is good but I've had better.. Service was okay.. Atmosphere is very loud.. Parking limited.. but, worth a trip.. if you're looking to try a new ramen spot!

FLWM0jScd1-_8ODeKxyEyA.text: Oh boy, I REALLY want to give this place 5 stars, but I can't. The ramen is top-shelf. VERY tasty and the food quality is so good! My main complaint is that every time I've been there, the add-ins are cold. For Pete's sake, but the extra egg in the broth so I don't have to warm it up! Now, if I ordered straight off the menu and didn't add anything, I would not have been the wiser and given 5 stars. It's THAT good! However, I don't think hot food is too much to ask for. My buddy John swears that this is the best ramen in town, but I can't abide the cold stuff on the side. Sorry, buddy. That being said, the curry ramen is pretty special. You should go for that alone. I LOVE that they are open until 11pm, as I get off work sometimes at 9:30 or 10 and can still grab a bite. They don't look at you funny for coming in late either. Parking is easy, they usually have something interesting on TV and the staff is very nice. There is this weird music thing where you hear songs you know, but not by the people you know. I find that odd.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Tatsu - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Curry Ramen. Added an egg and ground pork.
Photo of Ramen Tatsu - Las Vegas, NV, United States

b3zR4JEnkjwvvu3MPo5m5g.text: if youre looking for a late night ramen craving, i would definitely recommend this place..   Pros: -ramen is fresh!             -they have a lil bit more selection of finger food       than most ramen place.             -price is affordable.  Cons: a little bit slow bringing the food for a slow night.   i still give it a 5 star coz the food taste  over powered the slow process of bringing food out

qz1zXjZ4MR_khhtStOteIA.text: Such a cute restaurant. One of the best ramen places in vegas with a rustic atmosphere and wide menu choices. The service is quick and friendly and there is never a long wait to be seated. It's also right next door to a bunch of fun family and friendly activities. Love tatsu

umn3N3CVfnYhaAv5IkJs-w.text: Oh.... my.... GOSH! This place has the best ramen I have ever had (tastes like ramen i've had in Cali but almost better)! We use to go to Bachi Burger for their ramen, but they stopped serving ramen. Decided to check this place out because of the pics and reviews. My family absolutely loved it! We ordered the Miso Ramen, Spicy Miso Ramen, and Deluxe Ramen. The broth wasn't salty and was very tasty (we all finished eating the broth it was so good), the pork was delicious and almost melted in your mouth, and the staff is very friendly and made us feel welcomed! This will now be our go to place whenever we're in vegas. Seriously, if you want some good ramen you need to check this place out!

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Tatsu - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso Ramen with added egg and added spice!

QY5DRYJu-3D80wC2YWznzg.text: Ramen Tatsu is not my first restaurant pick when I crave for ramen, but when all the other ramen restaurants have a one to two hour wait, this is my go to place.  Depending on what you order, your ramen will come with different toppings. I like the miso ramen because it has corn on it, which not a common thing to find in ramen at other restaurants. If you have the taste buds for extremely spicy foods, my family loves the EXTRA spicy miso ramen. My family likes to compete to see who can handle it the best :P They also have the Chashu Rice Bowls or Fried Rice that is really tasty and good for anyone who doesn't feel like eating ramen.  The staff is friendly, food comes out quick, food is good, and the setting is cute.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Tatsu - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso ramen
Photo of Ramen Tatsu - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso ramen

BE36VyxZ9DKn4Xni-O9opA.text: If you know ramen then just skip this place. The ramen was average, the takoyaki and gyoza were both frozen variety and the paking lot is a hassle to get in and out of.   The service was good but it was also slow.

rwI7YnYh3geqRxdiOLzstQ.text: I'm half Japanese and I know good Ramen when I taste it! This place is authentic and the atmosphere is very welcoming. I always go with my mom (who is from Japan) and she loves this place!!! We always get the same thing Tonkatsu, Spicy Miso Ramen, Takoyaki, and Gyoza.  Go and try this place before everyone finds out how good it is.

kqasumQbvvdgnFas-c5DZw.text: Oddly enough, the husband and I were craving ramen on a hot, humid day in Vegas. We usually go to Ramen Sora, but decided to check out a different place this time around. Decided on Ramen Tatsu over Hiromaru, since "fusion ramen" sounded too weird and complicated. They are located right across the street from 168 Market. I don't like this plaza at all. It feels too crowded and the parking is retarded. Hard to explain, but you will know what I'm talking about when you go there.   They were pretty busy on a Saturday afternoon, but we were able to get seated right away. Our server was polite and friendly. I felt that she handled servicing all the customers very well by herself, including the couple sitting next to us. They were flagging her down for every little thing and asking a lot of questions (yeah, they were one of those). I ordered the Shoyu Ramen and a mini curry bowl. The broth for the Shoyu Ramen had a good flavor, not too rich but also not bland. I felt that there were a good amount of noodles. The curry was great! NO VEGGIES, and I believe the meat they used in it was pork. Definitely my kind of curry! It wasn't watery and tasted very good. I'm not sure who the owners are, but this place looks and feels like an authentic Japanese restaurant. My husband liked it as well, despite being located in  a kind of run down plaza. Small price to pay for good food I guess.  I strongly believe Ramen Tatsu deserves a much higher rating!! They have excellent ramen and curry, so I will definitely be back soon!

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Tatsu - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Katsu Curry
Photo of Ramen Tatsu - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Mini Curry
Photo of Ramen Tatsu - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu Ramen with no green onions

2J85XInHC8uYaiE2DPblsw.text: Of all the ramen places in LV, this is my favorite. They serve ramen just like you can find in most places in Japan.  Soup taste and the noodle firmness is just right.  Nothing fancy or unique about it but my wife and I both love Tatsu for the soup taste and their noodle. Everytime the ramen is cooked right.  My second choice is Misoya Tomi for very unique and tasty miso ramens and third will be Yagyu (really at home taste for most Japanese, just make sure you order the noodle firm so they don't over cook).

ZVk-OZQG0e0FyD6qVuTDMg.text: Do they have Tsukemen? Is it good? Are other items good too?  Yes, Yes and Yes.  Tatsu is totally underrated. They deserve way better rating than 3.5 - thus 5 stars to help bump up the rating.  To me, Tatsu comes close to Monta, Sora and Fukumimi (and Shoku, for that matter), if not better. And so far, tsukemen (with authentic, special thick noodle!) is only available at Tatsu (except Hiromaru but don't count).  If you haven't, try the deluxe ramen - it's a tasting menu for their ramen. Also, fried rice and gyoza are pretty good too.  If you tried a long ago before the ownership fuss, give them a second chance.  My wife has more unforgiving tastes than myself (looking at you, Guy Savoy), but she approves Tatsu too. Consider this review two votes.  We want good restaurants to stay.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Tatsu - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tsukemen
Photo of Ramen Tatsu - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Karaage
Photo of Ramen Tatsu - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Menu

Hrd86aR0NUauEC96LFvASg.text: This is my go to for Ramen!!! The prices are just as great as the food!!! Some places you get what you pay for. But not here!!! You get MORE!!! Flavor is always on point! Sooo worth the wait!!!

SHoU2hzvzzQzE7h2sjBzJg.text: Absolutely a great Ramen place in the Spring Mountain area. Parking can be a bit difficult in a crowded strip mall. But it's well worth it for the Spicy Miso.   There has never been a long wait. Service is quick and friendly. Asahi drafts are cheap and you better order the kimchee for an appetizer.   Every time I go I think that I will try something new. But every time the amazing Spicy Miso calls my name and I dig into a delicious bowl of awesomeness.

eSvDzCclI6khubUXGAY2hw.text: This is an ok place for ramen it wasn't the best ramen I have had in town but it is pretty good . Place is quiet and the staff are really nice.

mbvKKpY0LHyTqoHPTygdhA.text: This is now my favorite ramen spot in town! Service and food 5 stars. The best part is their happy hour, which is from 3-6 pm and everything (that i like) is $3! Their seared Chashu is the BEST thing ever along with their katsu curry bowl! Their spicy miso is absolutely to die for as well, considering they use habanero, it is spicier than most spicy ramens in town, but tastes better than them all. I can't speak highly enough about them and i have tried almost every ramen spot in town now. I still don't know how Monta has the reputation it has when this place poops all over them.

0IkV-9nzF-U-4p_jJqSNSg.text: Great food, great service, food comes out very fast and I loved how the server spoke to me in Japanese as soon as she realized we were Japanese. Definitely coming back again :)

tQekhpMKB5_SApW9xsGbAw.text: Great food and great service! I'm not much of a ramen person but decided to try their miso ramen based on the reviews. It was pretty good, but I prefer something spicier. My husband and I also tried their chahan and karage. A little too oily for my taste but again still delicious. Will definitely come back and try other dishes.

yVDFrLiWdxLEJmq1GBXxmg.text: I have been there 3 times, and every time it was just outstanding!  Love there happy hour pupu menus which is great!  The takoyaki melts in your mouth, the gyoza is outstanding, and their Japanese style char siu is the BOMB!   Soooooo tender and melts in your mouth.  Of course their ramen is excellent and I just love their curry!  One of my best place to dine!

JiOoyDiqd0hOBggGokkGAA.text: Two visits in two days. That says something! Came here and had the tonkotsu ramen. Amazing! The broth is better than any place I've been in LA. Rich and full of flavor.  His chashu is unbelievable. Braised and seared, it's a must try. The gyoza are mini size, but pack a wallop of flavor. Karaage chicken come out in huge pieces, very moist with a great crunch.  His cold ramen with dipping sauces is fantastic, especially the sesame dipping sauce. And it's presented exquisitely.  Asahi on draft is a huge plus! Expect gracious hospitality, and amazing service.  This is now on my "must list" each time I visit Vegas!

jBKwANGy_3Y-ddckhkUegg.text: The chasiu is incredible! The broth is incredible! Even the gyoza was honestly the best I've had! Time to head home back to the OC...

lbp8HCrBgr3F1_zl_3LcqA.text: So this by far is the best ramen I have (even better than Jinya.) The waitress was so kind and the atmosphere was so nice and welcoming. It was not crowded I came in around 1 pm. I ordered a spicy ramen w/ goyza , which I have to say was perfectly cooked ! Nobody ever cooks the goyza right but this place hands down is the best & you get to make your own goyza sauce which is entertaining as you wait for your food . The pricing is fair and not so expensive ! I should have went during their happy hour. But seriously I wish I could of left a bigger tip . Great place & excellent food ! Great service !

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Tatsu - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Goyza
Photo of Ramen Tatsu - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Best Ramen

vIoMLksqH9bw5tQpd8qrMA.text: My sister and I are ramen fanatics and read some great reviews about this place. It definitely sustained our ramen craving. The broth was great, noodles were perfect for me, and the pork was so flavorful and even had a hint of sweetness.   Our server was the sweetest lady ever! Makes the experience even better! opC9H5gig2N-yWGWMFBYXQ.text: So, I was a bit depressed that Tonkatsu Kiyoshi is not open on Sunday.  After filling up the gullet at HK Star on Mothers Day, I wanted to get some tonkatsu for the mother in laws to have at her place for dinner.  So I was calling in an order and realized that they were closed on Sundays.  As I was planning to pick up some to go items from Asian BBQ and Noodles, I saw that Ramen Tatsu sign advertising tonkatsu so I decided to give this place a shot:  a.  Where is everyone?  On a prime mothers day Sunday at lunch, the place had, three people.    b.  Take out - I was ordering take out, so I decided to forego any noodles and went for tonkatsu, tonkatsu with curry and an order of fried rice.  - Fried Rice - Very tasty, a nice firm consistency with great taste and plenty of small bits of meat.  I enjoyed this very much.  Not sure what was all in it as I just ate it all .  Yeah, I did give some to the mother in law, but took some home too.....  - Tonkatsu with Curry - Since this was take away, the tonkatsu was packed separately of the curry.  The tonkatsu was decent, no real wow factor for me, yet it was very edible.  Just not memorable.  the curry is pretty tasty. I like the dark color and the richness of the curry.  There was no veggies in it like carrots or potatoes to give the curry a bit of flavor and excitement.  It was just curry.  The food as I said was decent, just not anything memorable. The packaging of the take out was good, separating the curry from everything, but the presentation inside the boxes were a bit minimal.  In fact, if anything, the servings were a bit on the small side.  The service is five star!  The waitress was very pleasant and gave me a glass of water while I waited.   I definitely will be coming back soon to try their ramen and other dishes. I like the fact that it is not too busy but I am bit concerned that they are not too busy either.  GK says try this place out, it is authentic and dry nice.  I just have to try a bit more of the food to tie this a 4 star or more...

Gcz_kGSVUwsT97fNUlMVNQ.text: Highly recommended go to Ramen place! Super tasty miso broth with awesome pork that melts in your mouth almost like butter! Takoyaki is a delight!   It's a busy plaza and parking space sucks but we will definitely come back.

7mOaf-v4aDIWC37T2bz17g.text: So I had some of the spicy level 1 deluxe and wow! If you like spicy Ramen this is the place to go. I only had the level 1 and my mouth was on fire. They have a level 2 and 3!

0MoihLQyXMzKLP7eo6U5kQ.text: Another place that I recommend that you go early unless you dont mind waiting.  The ramen is great and the service is awesome.

B_UsxmU3uXiK7V5-CJiCTQ.text: Recently I've been on a Las Vegas ramen binge the past couple weeks and I think this place is definitely one to visit. It's more spacious than Monta, which is where we usually go.   The service was fantastic. She made sure to clear empty plates but not come around so much that she imposed. She was very polite and always made sure our drinks were filled.   We visited 430 on a Wednesday and were pleasantly surprised to hear it was still happy hour. Some apps and asahi for $3 each, cant beat that. I like how on the menu they describe the broth very well.  Shoyu ramen: the broth was well balanced and it wasn't too salty, but still had a light soy sauce flavor. This ramen comes with an egg which was a plus.  Tonkatsu shoyu ramen: basically a milkier version of the shoyu ramen. You can tell they really cooked it with bones so the flavors really come out.   Takoyaki: a good balance of sauce on top. Usually I burn my tongue on this but it was nice that for once it was served at a temp that didn't hurt.  Small curry rice: served with a side of picked radishes. 'Nuff said. ----but on a real note, I was pretty stoked because I was craving curry and it was at the same standard if you went to just a Japanese curry place.  Gyoza: pretty standard but it felt like there was more than what restaurants usually serve.  All this plus an Asahi for $30. Not too shabby. I'll be back Ramen Tatsu.

Mq0GS4mfQCKvdkWhlgVMdw.text: Came here a few nights ago since we knew Jinya and Monta had long wait times. This place surprisingly had long wait times too (my boyfriend and I waited around 40 minutes here) but we thought we should try somewhere new instead of our usual ramen spots.  My biggest gripe is that this place does not like to do any accommodations for customers. When we sat down , we wanted to order tonkastu ramen but the waitress told us they have been out of it which was kinda inconvenient , they should have put a sign on their door that said they're out of it since it's a popular menu choice & we waited so long to get tonkatsu ramen in mind. I asked the waitress if I can switch out the tonkatsu broth w/ miso broth instead and she said no but I can order their miso ramen. My issue w/ ordering their miso ramen is that it has corn and bean sprouts in it which makes the broth taste terrible (mainly just the bean sprouts w/ my experience at Fukumimi) & I just cared about getting pork, mushrooms and broth I like for my ramen. I asked if it's possible to switch out the corn and bean sprouts for different toppings. At first the waitress said no they can't do that but she can just remove those two toppings (and I will still be paying same price). She also suggested that I could order the shio or shoyu ramen since those don't have corn or bean sprouts in it like the miso ramen. However , I prefer heavier broths like tonkatsu or miso. I showed her on their menu the toppings I wanted to be substituted is pretty much almost the same price as corn and bean sprouts so she finally she agreed to doing my order after I asked and mentioned that twice.  Food came out quick which was the only good thing for waiting so long. All the toppings were really cold. I tried some of my boyfriend's shoyu which didn't taste good at all , thankfully their miso wasn't bad. So glad I didn't go w/ waitress' recommendation to order shoyu. Other ramen places have chili paste or spice seasonings on the table available but this place charges you extra.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Tatsu - Las Vegas, NV, United States

n54MWBBpzxuWQCil9T17cw.text: Love this ramen spot! They have the spicy options that are perfect for all spicy lovers. You can make any ramen spicy. There are six levels of spicy. They go up to Jigoku "Hell" Level 3. Wonderful housemade paste with ghost chili peppers and habanero! You can also choose to add additional toppings. Yum! I love customization. The gyoza is tasty, as well. I highly recommend this place! Legit!

wg5mpeHg2jBwWxlgdT7gug.text: Great reviews on Yelp so I went here since it's open until 11pm. I got seated right away, they do have few bar seating and half dozen tables, it's quite a small shop. The food came out pretty quick like a typical ramen shop. Not quite a open kitchen either like most ramen shops.   I ordered the tonkatsu shoyu ramen, the flavor was pretty good not as rich broth as I have had at other places. My only problem was their food was on the salty side. If it was lighter it would have been better and I would have rated them higher, also the noodles were also to Al dente for my taste. I felt the noodles should have been softer, need a few more minutes of cooking time. The pork slices on top of the noodles also was a bit salty. I also ordered a pork belly rice bowl but that too was salty.  It was decent but due to the improperly cooked noodles and saltyness not my favorite.

YwX_ewIHBqM5BsxlG2JSxw.text: They are located next to District One. Plenty of parking space around.   I went here couple of times and still did not like it.   I decided to try their Tsukemen (soup on the side). Price is reasonable $10.70.   It came with a flat thick yellow noodle. I thought the noodle was hard to chew and tasteless. The brooth was thick which was expected for Tsukemen, but it was way too salty and has a weird after taste (as if it was re-cooked many times). The charsu was okay, it was cold and taste can improved. It did not come with bamboo shoot or mushroom but it did come with boiled egg.   Service was great, however. It was fast and timely.  I also had the macaroon ice cream (not pictured). That's the best part of my lunch. I enjoyed it more than my ramen.   I saw they have Happy Hour menu with great prices. So if I decided to come back, I would try their HH menu instead.

uitjIeSFZhh3l9bZXPuV_g.text: This review is long over due as with my other ones.  But I'm finally revisiting my draft reviews in preparation for my upcoming trip to sin city.  I want new spots to try out or do I make a come back?   This ramen house was recommended to me by one of my yelper friend whom I wish would write more reviews of all these places he grubs at.  And this boy eats out ALOT and is always trying new places out!  Anyway.  We finally made it here.  I went with my usual preference of Tonkotsu ramen c seaweed, tamago, green onions, butter and chaschu.  Loved the consistency of the broth and flavors were right on. Delish.  Service was prompt  and polite.  I was pleased our waitress spoke Nihongo.  It authenticated my dining experience here.  So I might definitely return!

4bwjwybskxnKMKIyb6ILEA.text: This is great ramen.  I was there at around 9:00 pm on a weeknight, and it was not busy, which was good for me, but understandably not great for business.  I am just so tired of waiting forever for Monta, and I'm not the biggest fan of Sora, and Fukumimi was a little too far for me that day.  Anyways, next time I'm in Vegas, I'll be sure to go there instead of Monta.  I had the tonkotsu.  The soup was perfect, the chashu was amazing, and the egg was perfectly done.  I seriously had no complaints.  I've eaten tonkotsu ramen in Hakata, Japan when I lived there for two years, and Ramen Tatsu took me back.  Prices were very reasonable too.  Check this place out!

lvIsllMN2Ip36I28oJ_cTA.text: So this is my favorite ramen place in vegas. A lot of people say that sora or monta is better but I can't really compare them (since, I never ate there). However, I don't ever want to put in the effort to go to sora or monta because the wait is aways super long. When, I can just go to Ramen Tatsu, for what I think is the BEST ramen place.   Not only do they have excellent ramen that taste amazing and balanced but they have curry, that tastes like its from the gods. They even have a ramen that mixes the curry with shoyu and it tastes so good. My dad says that the taste reminds him of when he was in Japan. The taste is very authentic and they are always so fast.   The ambience of the place is wonderful because it really is like you are in a ramen shop in japan. It's small but by far my favorite place to get ramen, curry, and takoyaki.

q-mADN1s9yHALyfURtmDcg.text: I keep forgetting to check in and write a review for this place every time I'm here because when I get my food I just chow down!!!  I have a bit of a ramen addiction and if you do too this is a great place to satisfy your cravings!! I get the tonkotsu which comes with thin noodles. The broth is made from pork bone marrow and veggies boiled for many hours! It's absolutely delicious! I get no meat so they add more mushrooms for me! And if you like spicy get the spicy sauce on the side! I highly recommend to everyone!

w2GbCksh74xlRCA6DKf2iA.text: Saw the signage for a new ramen restaurant that was going to be opening soon while picking up dinner next door. Fast forward about a month and I saw a few reviews from fellow Yelpers and most were just so so. In spite of that, I still wanted to try it. What can I say, I am a sucker for checking out new Japanese restaurants. So I asked Leos to go with me on Monday. Unfortunately they are closed on Mondays. So we went to a new Vietnamese pho restaurant instead. [Visit 1] So after waiting another 22 hours, I went back to try my luck at Ramen Tatsu (on their official grand opening day) after clocking out at work for the day. The restaurant had 2-3 parties already when I arrived, but soon after placing my order for a Tatsu Ramen Deluxe I realized I was alone in the restaurant with just the staff. Nervously I noticed that I was feeling oddly warm, as if I was still outside in the 111 degree heat wave, but it turned out to just be a weak AC unit. The Tatsu Ramen Deluxe - Tonkotsu + Shoyu based ramen with 6 pieces of Chasiu and vegetables, seaweed, 1/2 egg. The presentation makes it look bigger than it really is, reminiscent of the Frilled Lizard (1.bp.blogspot.com/-ocXif...) The broth was decent, the noodles was cooked well. [Latest Visit from yesterday] I ate already before making an unscheduled stop at Ramen Tatsu. So I only ordered their Chasiu Rice Bowl. Which is just a basic bowl of steamed rice with pieces of chasiu, green onions and a tiny bit of sauce on it. It tasted fine, albeit a little dry with all the rice and very little sauce. But was difficult to eat without potentially dropping pieces of chasiu on the table. I tried the broth from the Tonkotsu Ramen and Shoyu Ramen that my dining companions ordered. The Tonkotsu broth has definitely improved, and was definitely way better than any of the ramen I tried at the recent Ramen Festival at the Rio. The portion for the ramen is what I considered smallish. But the extra $1.50 for "noodle refills" is a great relative value. Other observations: * I asked for the Tsukemen, but it is no longer on the menu. * The restaurant is typically pretty empty, great if you don't like to wait for ramen, which is supposed to be fast food. * Split check request is handled without any fuss. Definite plus. Decor: Nice and simple. During holidays, they will have seasonally decorations,at least they have put up Halloween theme decorations right now. Cleanliness: Very clean Service: Friendly and thoughtful Probability of return visits: Moderately high More than a plain 3 stars, but not quite to 4 stars yet.

THdknhk2P5tsr13IdXSBgQ.text: First time here and I decided to try the Deluxe Tonkatsu ramen. It was a big bowl with plenty of spread; omg the pork was so tender and delicious. The noodles were almost perfect. I was, however, looking for more seasoning in their broth but it was still close to amazing.   Also, I tried the curry. The taste reminded me of childhood memories but I was quite disappointed that there were no potatoes, carrots or anything in the curry itself. Not even a piece of chicken. It could have been much better.   Outside of the restaurant, parking absolutely sucks. It is in a location with tons of restaurants and shops and it's hard to find parking during peak hours.    This was my first ramen experience in Vegas. It wasn't a bad one. And it wasn't great. But it sure isnt the last. The quest continues.

vP2lA60CXQGAxXYVuFXNog.text: Stopped by cause I was craving some Tsukemen (we don't have really anyone in Arizona that has this). When the meal came out my expectations were immediately met from a look standpoint. Pretty thick and flavorful broth and the noodles were nice and firm. The Chasu slices had a good amount of balance between fat and meat and once you placed it in the broth it instantly became a melt in your mouth texture.  The soft boiled egg was a little overdone but I'll forgive Ramen Tatsu just because it still tasted good.   Overall, a great experience at Ramen Tatsu and the closest I can get to True Tsukemen.

-wTu7AQkT75_MZn_IHkrVA.text: Been coming here on and off for a year and i have not had a bad experience. If you love ramen and other types of Japanese cuisine, I highly recommend this restaurant. I6ji6CNNq0_Nh3zxgMmPfg.text: Beautiful setting and decor, really fair prices, delicious ramen and especially tasty chashu pork. The service was really great, we had a sweet  who served with a sing-song voice (I wish I loved anything as much as she seemed to love her work). Our table of three split an order of chicken karaage, three ramen bowls with some extra toppings (I got miso ramen), and a chashu rice bowl, and the bill came out to $14 a person (which simply does not happen in San Francisco where I'm from). The ramen was tasty, especially the two thick and fatty, cathartic chashu pieces in it, and the chashu bowl was elegant and delicious too.   Basically, the food was on point, the interior is cute, and our server was like something from an anime. She even greets people in Japanese as they leave / enter. Can't be beat. !

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Tatsu - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso ramen with a $5 chashu bowl in the back.

YyVAEeASctnDUEM806jGRQ.text: I've been to the 4 or 5 ramen joints on Spring Mountain and I've found my favorite with Tatsu.  There's a great selection of bowls: Shoyu, Shio, Miso, Tonkotsu, Curry, and others. When there's a wide selection like this, I find usually there is a loss in quality - as if having only two or three bowls like other ramen spots allows them to output great flavor in a speedy service. At Tatsu, you get the complete package: quick service and high quality flavor in each bowl; each distinct and unique from the next.   By now, I've tried them all (they now also have customizable options for additional ingredients). Over the months that I've been coming in here, I've noticed I'm not the only one that prefers Tatsu.  Business is doing well - more tables have been set in place, two flat screens were installed, and the menu has expanded.   This summer, they introduced Cold Ramen - a different delicious take on ramen for a hot day - and also Tsukemen which has thicker noodles with a dipping sauce of a hint of fish flavor.  I keep coming back because it's the best and the entire menu is top notch. I wouldn't be surprised if this hidden gem gets more and more popular in the near future.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Tatsu - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Another one of their newer items on the menu, Tsukemen. Thick noodles with dipping sauce with a bit of fish flavor.
Photo of Ramen Tatsu - Las Vegas, NV, United States. One of their newer additions, Cold Ramen. Just like the ones I&#39;ve had in Japan on a hot day.

qJZUquUIPoNY0_Bn7zXq8A.text: I love love this place! I have never waited in line! Their ramen is sooooo good!! The employees are super nice and happy!  my new fave ramen spot! If you're in Vegas and craving for ramen, check this place out!!  Don't wait in line for 45 mins or more at some other ramen places in china town!

sXZl78lU6_21A2tsphXFUg.text: New fave ramen spot in Vegas...Wow! Full disclosure, never been to Japan, but I've had ramen in many different cities (HK, SF, Vancouver, Honolulu, Seattle, Edmonton, Calgary) so I'd like to think I have had decent exposure to ramen noodles. We love this place! Rich, flavourful broth, nice thin ramen noodles cooked perfectly to al dente, wonderfully fresh accoutrements...definitely in the top two best ramen we've had. Super casual spot, very reasonably priced (I had the deluxe for $11 USD, wife had the tonkatsu for $8). Asahi and Sapporo on tap. Takoyaki was LEGIT (light and crispy on the outside, inside moist and fluffy, with very flavourful octopus stuffing. Droooooooool.

hS4CnyIBvGB2cpwq6z0hrA.text: I know there are a lot of ramen places to choose from in Vegas but we specifically were craving tsukemen because I'm all about that dippin' ramen life. If I can just find and review ramen restaurants that serves tsukemen all day every day, that would be awesome.  The service was quick and we were seated right away at the bar. The waitress explained the levels of spiciness to us since we were intrigued. My husband ordered a spicy tsukemen while I ordered it in a mild spiciness. The original basic tsukemen is not spicy at all.  Mild was actually spicier than I thought but still good. However, right away, I noticed the noodles aren't like your usual tsukemen noodle. They just seemed like regular cold cooked ramen noodle? I'm used to the tsukemen noodles being incredibly chewy and chunkier. The tsukemen came with two slices of pork, a seaweed and two soft boiled eggs. No frills and bells and whistles here.   The broth was good, but much saltier than I anticipated. I did enjoy the flavor, but was overwhelmed by how salty it was. I know that tsukemen broth is supposed to be very rich but I was definitely saltier than I usually like. Nonetheless, this place did help satisfy the tsukemen itch we had been having.

dExm4bcZF4-zMbExpA9f9g.text: Good customer service. We managed to get a seat this time because usually when we pass by the restaurant is a full house.   We ordered: Gyoza (6 pieces) and Kim Chee fried rice for appetizer, Deluxe ramen, Tonkotsu Shoyu ramen and the Tonkotsu ramen as our main dishes and then we shared a slice of mango and New York cheesecakes.  Overall, the ramen portions were perfect - the noodles are thick. The broths are quite tasty. We left being really full. The cheesecake slices were really small; not sure if $3.80 was worth the price. But, it's a great place to try

The waitress checked on us to see if we needed again at least 3x. The decor was quaint and cute! I definitely would go back! Rumor has it there is one in LA area this one is almost 300 miles away.

EbLKNbOcJTcHWKx30TDLRA.text: A co-worker of mine looked at me and said that he felt a cold coming on. I knew I had the perfect treatment. Ramen Tatsu for lunch, specifically the spicy miso ramen for him.   We went to one of  my favorite ramen spots. In my opinion this is some of the best Ramen you can find here in Las Vegas. This hidden gem is a small shop nestled between two other shops.   We were greeted by a smile by the super friendly server we were used to seeing. "Sit anywhere you'd like" she said with a BIG smile.   We sat at a table where she promptly took our drink orders. We ordered the spicy miso ramen, miso ramen, a large fried rice minus the pork, and a house salad.   As always, the food did not disappoint. If I could buy a bottle of the dressing they use on their house salad I would. The spicy miso ramen had my co worker sweating it out while I enjoyed my pork free fried rice and salad. Everything was so full of flavor.   The service here is always perfect. Lots of smiles, very attentive, and the food is always served quickly.   I highly recommend this ramen shop.

SAcBSLM6mHrEuzlqoon0qg.text: I've been to ramen tatsu twice now and I've enjoyed both visits. The most recent visit I got the tonkatsu ramen. I love that this place is still not super popular so there's never really a wait. The ramen here is also very well priced.   The tonkatsu ramen had a creamy rich broth. It comes with thin noodles which I like but you can choose your noodle option. The noodles were soft but still had a good bite to it. The ramen comes with woodear mushrooms, charsu pork slices, which melted in your mouth, and green onions. I didn't care for the mushroom. It was super crunchy and flavorless. I would have rather had bean sprouts or bamboo shoots. My friend got the spicy tonkatsu ramen. The soup definitely had a kick. I liked the flavor better but eating the whole bowl would have been a little spicy for me.   My other friend ordered the spicy miso ramen. The miso flavor is potent in a good way. The next time I go back I'll order that.

wr4LeBQXsotXabqF_BCc8A.text: Maybe ramen just isn't my thing.   I had it a couple times at a place down the street and enjoyed it.   Tonight, was one of the saddest eating experiences of my life.  I took like 9 bites and just couldn't eat anymore because I disliked it so much.  I got the tonkotsu shoyo.   Just something about the broth tasted so bad to me.  Like something in my brain telling me that I shouldn't be eating it.   But every other review seems to think it's fantastic.  The meat in it was okay.   And I'm sure their noodles are prepared correctly but they were too hard for my taste.    Price was reasonable at $7.77 but my mouth is in a state of morning.    My wife is Asian and she liked what she got.   Maybe my whiteness stops me from enjoying Japanese Ramen.     Atmosphere is cute, intimate and quiet but won't be back.

wFLPt5DQEPROzZcUWgazNg.text: This is a small hidden gem that I found thanks to all the Yelp reviews! Located at the small strip where District One, Hachi and many other popular eateries.  My mom and I came in today around noon. It's a small restaurant and I recommend coming in early.    We waited a couple minutes and were seated. There was only one server but I have to say, she was very lively and attentive. We ordered and it only took a few minutes to get our food.   We ordered Chasiu Bowl from the regular menu and Tonkatsu Shoyu medium spicy from the Special menu.  Tonkotsu Shoyu is spicy and had sliced pork in a delicious rich, flavorful and slightly creamy broth. . The noodles itself were delicious -- perfectly cooked with the perfect amount of chew.  My mom enjoyed the rice bowl, Chasiu Bowl. It has tender ground pork, seaweeds and rice.  The portion looked small but in the end we had leftovers! The price is so reasonable, cost like $15 for two dishes. I can't wait to go back.

J6Ik1YzTYVD6YgPVlPTn2Q.text: The ramen and tamago are above average but the broth and meats are average.  It is not as flavorful compared to Jinya, but the wait is only 15 minutes on a weekend and the service is friendly and fast.  Parking is surprisingly acceptable in a small lot.  We did not have to park far away at 6:30 PM on a Sunday.  We enjoyed our visit and will make it part of our rotation the next time we are in Las Vegas.

nWfPDcT_WURohvysibslZQ.text: This is probably going to be my new favorite spot. First time here and I already enjoy the vibe. It's small spot but not a hole in the wall like Monta.The minute we came in the waitress greeted us and sat us down. She gave us the menu, took our drink and appetizer order and came out less than than a minute later. Yup, that was quick. She was pleasant, friendly and smiled throughout the whole service plus explained the menu to us which is a plus.   We ordered gyoza, chasu ramen, seared chasu plate with kimchee and fried rice and the Katsu curry plate.  All portions were perfect. Not too small nor too big. I had the katsu curry plate and it was delish! It was just as good as Zen's curry ( my favorite Japanese curry spot). The curry was pleasantly spicy but not too much.   After eating, my party stayed a but longer just to chat it up and the awesome part was that no one rushed us to get up and refilled our drinks at least two times even when the restaurant started to get overly packed. If it weren't for that, I would've given this place four stars. I like this place a lot and will be back soon to try their ramen.

XhQaBxvGLtw7Nh09iGiC-g.text: Why is it that I have to go to Las Vegas to have the best ramen outside of Japan?  There isn't a place in Los Angeles or Orange County that comes close to this place.  If you're visiting Las Vegas, this place is a must visit.

yHSu1j5mtMH-TXcZnK4SFQ.text: Sooooooo good! Bf brought me here the service was awesome.. I did add my own raw jalapenos once we got home but I know to get extra spicy next time

Y5ECyNq8TFxgRhtFLA4iKA.text: Really liked this place!  Small and hidden off Jones. Don't get discouraged about the parking, it's pretty much like that in Chinatown all over. Food is worth the wait, so stick it out. The ramen here is fresh and very flavorful. Must try the shoyu ramen. That broth is killer! Make sure to add the extra items to yours...they are priced very reasonably.  Waitress was real sweet and attentive.  We were a large party...came 1 1/2 before close. Didn't feel rushed at all.   Will visit again

QaYZ8lqhGDs5FL-7JRLmpA.text: Consistently great! Hubby, son, and I walked in on Monday afternoon (Happy hour time) and we were welcomed with "Thank you for coming!" Our lovely server lady brought a set of toddler utensils and a bowl then took our beverage order. White House wine, Asahi ($3 each) and left us to peruse the menu. I always order the same yummy ramen. (Tonkatsu ramen with egg and bean sprout.) Hubby orders spicy ramen. A side of rice and happy hour karaage for our son. Attentive service, yummy food... It's our one and only place for ramen.

fbZ_5GAe2j0nsdI0U8UtXw.text: Ramen Tatsu is a worthy competition to Monta Ramen, with no lines of waiting customers. The soup base of the Tonkatsu ramen was so packed with flavor it was almost creamy. The gyoza tasted just like Monta. The Shoyu ramen was another winner. Although I prefer the Pork chasu at Monta, Ramen Tatsu presented a thicker cut of chasu that was also full of good flavor, just slightly different from Monta.  They also have a few dessert items like NY cheesecake, mango cheesecake, ice cream and Mochi ice cream.   Friendly and prompt service from Emy made the meal a pleasant and relaxing experience. No hurrying to finish my meal to make room for waiting customers. The size of the restaurant was slightly bigger than Monta. Give this place a try, it would be worth your time.

0fZo4FE5TCFIjqY8agkKVg.text: This review is way overdue, my apologies for waiting so long!!! this is by far my FAVORITE ramen place in town, why? because they have the BEST SERVICE! I'm all about great service, this little Japanese lady who worked there always greeted you with the cutest smile and attentive service.  I can't count how many times I was having a really bad day, but her positive attitude always influenced me, not to mention they are super easy going when it comes to customize the soup.  I can tell them I want my soup less salty, and she'll say "ok no problem", had it been another ramen restaurant (whose name start with "Sxxa" or "Mxxxxa"), they will give me a funny look as if I'm trying to make their job difficult.  Their ramen are super yummy too (probably because I customize the soup exactly the way I wanted), NOT once I had a bad service from here.  Some of my favorites are Karaage (fried chicken), Shio and Miso Ramen, today I just tried their spicy pork ramen, watch out on that one, they are not joking about "spicy" part, but it's soooo good :)  Thank you for the awesome service Ramen Tatsu!

4tjjiaYtGKFOchXprx_L9g.text: We love trying ramen places. This place is very nice inside. We ordered the miso, tonkatsu and tonkatsu shoyu ramen. Miso had good broth taste. The tonkatsu broth was missing something and the thin noodles had no flavor. The noodles on the tonkatsu shoyu were good but again broth was missing some flavor. We also ordered the karage it was ok definitely wasn't from scratch tasted like Tyson's frozen chicken. Overall it was ok to give it a try but probably would not go back.

VFHIG-MGcHx1mexNdUv0EA.text: Date & Time: Wednesday 3/3/15 @ 1:30pm  I've wanted to try a new ramen place, since Monta is always packed and has wait times over 45mins. I found this place with the help of some yelpers. I decided I can't go wrong with a place that offers ramen and appetizers.  I ordered: - Takoyaki - Tonkatsu - 1 Soyu Ramen (garlic chips and extra chasiu) - 1 Tonkatsu Ramen (extra chasiu and corn) - 3 Calpico drinks - 1 Sprite total about $40  Since i've only tried Monta and (my moms ramen), I'll be comparing the two (mom already wins).   I LOVE takoyaki and this place makes it so good, it's crisp on the outside and nice and creamy on the inside. The tonkatsu made with a cabbage salad and the tonkatsu sauce on the side, which was cooked to perfection. The tonkatsu was thick and crispy on the outside with the tender juicy pork on the inside. It was delicious.  When the ramen arrived the noodles were perfect, the soup was super flavorful and didn't need to add additional salt or soy sauce to it. Compared to monta's chasiu, this one is meaty in the middle and melt in your mouth on the sides (which is how it's suppose to be). I didn't enjoy the chasiu at Monta because it was like eating boiled fat (it was slippery, melty, and gooey).   If you want incredible ramen, come here. The waitress was super friendly and helpful. This small ramen restaurant should be deemed the best. The best thing is, it didn't make my love sick, he got so sick at Monta, he was scared to try Ramen again.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Tatsu - Las Vegas, NV, United States. soyu ramen and tonkatsu, I started eating and forgot to take a picture

KxmNsKfUJTkJu269bcYpNQ.text: Our new go to ramen spot here in Vegas and we've been to them all. Not to say that others are junk but this one is now our favorite. It's a little small, but all the best places are.    We are what's scientifically known as fatasses and you'll soon see why.  Keep in mind, the following was only for me and my 5 foot girlfriend. We started with the gyoza and it was seriously good. My gf ate almost all of them and she usually only eats one or two pieces. Then we had an egg with ground pork bowl, which was also very tasty, kinda like shin sen gumi in LA. We also got the small curry bowl (because I love curry) and it was on point! I would come here for just the curry, even though I would have to order a ramen just because my stomach is built that way.   Those were just the appetizers. Which we demolished. Then we got our ramen. I believe she had the shoyu ramen which I didn't really get to taste, well, because she ate it all. I got the tonkatsu shoyu ramen. I really liked it because usually the tonkatsu broths are a little on the heavy side but this one was flavorful and light. I would like to say we took some home, but no. We finished everything.   So anyways, we got dessert. Not just a little. We didn't save room for it at all, we just kinda stuffed it in there. We got the Vanilla mochi ice cream. This was only ok. My gf didn't like the skin because it was kind of hard. But we got the mango cheesecake and that was good! It was super creamy. So creamy in fact in inspired me to get the New York style as well. This one was eh.. Only ok too. It was hard and not as creamy. Or maybe it was too cold, probably because we got it after they already closed.   This is definitely the spot to go if you're craving a ramen fix.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Tatsu - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Ground pork bowl. YAAAASSS
Photo of Ramen Tatsu - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkatsu Shoyu Ramen

AtsRwUxXZR0U0Kw2-esxbg.text: First, their music is terrible...it sounded like meth addicts banging on pots and pans!  Next, their service was OK. The place was half empty and we still waited with empty drink glasses on multiple occasions.   On to the important part...THE FOOD!   I have to admit I used my buddy Philip T's review to adjust my dining choices! (I trust his reviews)  My GF and I both got the Tonkatsu with garlic chips, the thick noodles, extra chasu pork and some spicy sauce.   I found everything to be enjoyable, but honestly it will be hard to get me back here! Ramen Sora and Hiromaru both have a much better Tonkatsu, so it will be tough to convince me to come back!   I would give their food 3.5 stars, but the shitty music and poor service was enough to put them at 3 stars.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Tatsu - Las Vegas, NV, United States

Cba0n7bqmmcfKMAZRlipFg.text: Can I just say that this place is simply AMAZING! Why? Because we were greeted by the one and only server there who seated us as well, took our orders, and refilled our drinks without us ever asking for it. Oh and by the way it was a full house! She was so cheerful and sweet I loved it! By far the best ramen place I've been to. It was amazingly delicious and the price was definitely worth every cent! I couldn't have been more satisfied. We also ordered the kimchi fried rice. We will be coming back here I'm so glad I found this hidden joint. Just worth it!

NZVqxibQ7fBhDzsedtNKdg.text: New ramen place, and it's good. It's a nice change from the oh so popular straight Tonkotsu ramen. Albeit, that's my favorite. This one is tonkotsu yes, but the broth isn't as thick and relentless as you tonkotsuites may be used to. Def recommend getting the deluxe as you get 4 pieces of chashu, a full egg, kikurage, negi (green onions), and noodles. The only downside is the soup isn't very hot. I usually like it when the broth comes in piping hot.  Also got a side of gyoza. The gyoza is delicious, however it is super garlicky so expect to bring some breath mints with you at the very least. Or don't eat it at all before heading out to the strip. Unless you like honey badger and you don't care. Got the Karaage as well. My mom and I both thought it would be a chicken drumstick as advertised in the picture but alas no, it wasn't. And it was the least tasty at our table.  As for price - I think it's reasonable. And the service isn't bad at all. Get here before everyone notices there's a new ramen spot in town!

noP_gScZiKct_wlVjN0mOg.text: Real good ramen. Ordered the tonkotsu shoyu- it was delicious. Takoyaki was really good as well. Overall, good food & great service although the place is quite small. Will definitely be back for my ramen fix.

XMvmT3CNtd_OzrRuD2T-hg.text: My hubby and I love this Ramen Place!   The atmosphere is very authentic and traditional :) definitely reminded me of Japan!   I ordered the Spicy Miso and the hubs got Tonkatsu Shoyu Ramen ;)   We finished it off with some Yuzu Sorbet (a mandarin, lemon, grapefruit, and tangerine flavor) & green tea ice cream. Overall delicious, great customer service, and food!! Best ramen place for sure. Go at the late hours.

F3CiYhYhPMto8y1hJKUwEQ.text: The tonkotsu broth is amazing here, not too fatty and just the right flavor. In my opinion, flavorful and less fattier than Monta Ramen (even though I like Monta too).  The extra spicy is all overwhelming, it might just start a fire in the hole and the toilet will be your best friend. But def worth it!

2lkH8KsgccQSf-svii_kSw.text: My new favorite ramen in town.  I love monta, sora and this place. this place being the least expensive with great flavor. The soup is very thick which is my favorite style. I do not care for light broth ramen. Plus this is much less known than Sora or Monta, almost no wait at 4pm when I got there. Love it.

xjvvCABK3h0jwFsBv4IBdQ.text: Fantastic food, In fact the best fried rice in Las Vegas. The restaurant is very clean and everyone is very nice and welcoming

BqvW2Z6a9-_7MnfG_MylnQ.text: Glad to find a nice little ramen place. The spice level is jI ordered the Tonaktsu Ramen which was a perfect creamyish consistency. Just perfect. I found out they use ghost pepper so if you really like extra spice they have the level for you.

kHox48UyZqUGnjf_QDEjjQ.text: From the moment we walked in - I loved this place. Comparing it to other ramen spots around town, isn't a real comparison because this is Tatsu.. and Tatsu is a comfy spot with really good food and a cozy atmosphere.   We will be back - and often. Thanks for having a 30 minute wait at the place we went prior to Tatsu - it made me happy to try another when the afore mentioned place,  always gives less than stellar service and haphazard presentations.  Tatsu tastes home made and well crafted. Go there.   P.S. As a reminder .. just because you don't like something - does not mean that "it isn't good" Another recent review mentions that "ramen isn't his thing' so he gives the place 1 star. Seems legit. mA_rg2R80zPVWKaVU87_hg.text: This place is authentic Japanese ramen! Oyshi!   Every time I go I eat too much and that's a good thing! It is awesome and fast. The servers are the nicest people ever. Also personable! They make the best food and have wonderful service. I love Ramen Tatsu!!!!

Xae2hAjdL70v31wyjAwQjA.text: I'm not one to crave ramen a lot I usually go for the rice bowls but this place has changed that for me! Their ramen is so flavorful and I love the fact I can choose my own level of spicy (that's definitely a plus for me) I get tonokutsu soyo with med spice, and the spice is just right that leaves you satisfied but at the same time wanting more! I appreciate their menu as well because of all the visuals! This place has definitely become one of my favorites and their service is delightful and quick!

PCWB3976Z8Gk3Cx1nU37Yg.text: Awesome place. The ramen was top notch and I highly recommend this place to anyone. It was amazing and the service was great. I want to come again. Can't wait.

5TS7NCtpHn54ROjJEy3EWA.text: "A Japanese man walked into the currency exchange in New York City with 2000 yen and walked out with $72. The following week, he walked in with another 2000 yen, and was handed $66. He asked the teller why he got less money that week than the previous week. The teller said, "Fluctuations." The Japanese man stormed out, and just before slamming the door, turned around and shouted, "Fluc you Amelicans, too!" Ba-dum-ching! Source: Jokes4us.com Went on Tuesday 7-5-16 around 8PM for a late dinner. This restaurant is located on Jones between Desert Inn & Spring Mountain. $18.47 got me a shio ramen bowl, a small order of fried rice, an oolong tea, and an order of edamame. $7.77 shio ramen- The noodles were nice and thick and at first I thought the broth was kinda bland but after adding some shichimi it was perfect. I added an egg for an extra dollar. The portion size was larger than I expected for the price. A very good value! The chasu is kind of thin however and not as tender as Sora's version. Their fried rice is a steal for $3.77...absolutely delicious and I'm craving it again already! I also enjoyed their edamame which was served hot and salty in an adorable bowl which also held the shells. The server could not have been nicer. She was absolutely bending over backwards to make us happy! This place is a great value for the money and I really enjoyed coming here.

wXX-lwLtsLqd_7vRmcjxvQ.text: Came here last night as I wanted some comfort food after a long day at work. I would usually go to Ramen Kobo because it's only 5-7 minutes away, but I figured I should try out some new ramen places.   I got the shoyu ramen. The broth is a mix of chicken and pork with a little soy sauce. Toppings are half an egg and green onions, along with 2 pieces of pork. First off, I kinda liked the broth. For some reason, I felt like it's similar to a type of Korean soup base, which I bought from Greenland (I don't know how to say it, its all in Korean characters). The noodles were just okay. I traded off egg with my husband's kikurage (wood ear). He didn't like the kikurage at all, I guess it's an Asian thing. Wood ear was the same everywhere. The meat wasn't as tender as I expected.   Service was good. There was only one waitress while we were there but it wasn't crowded. We didn't have to wait long, not sure how it comes out when it's real lunch/dinner hours.

TUbaXbXN0ScxhD8suij51Q.text: We were recently in town for a tournament and the night before I we left town, we wanted to get something light to eat as we had been pigging out the whole trip. Ramen came to mind and we narrowed it down to two options. Monta and Ramen Tatsu. We ended up chosing Ramen Tatsu for its close proximity to us and we were glad we did.  The establishment was nice and clean, and though the restaurant isn't exactly large, there was plenty of space for us. The vibe was relaxed, which was a welcomed change of pace from our trip. The waitress was super attentive and pleasant.  The offerings on the menu was fairly diverse, so... if you didn't feel like Ramen, you definitely had a lot of other options. Food was tasty and priced very well.  5 stars out of 5. Good food. Easy to get to. Relaxed environment. Not expensive. Definitely coming back to here soon!  We were at Ramen Tatsu at 9-930PM on a Friday night. The parking lot gets kind of packed due to the surrounding businesses. Leave a little early to account for parking. Being late for a date is not attractive. :P

4hLGq3Tdahki8aTkrO9Khw.text: This stuff is good, guys. Super good ramen with that comfort food feel!  Ramen Tatsu is located in one of the busiest strip malls on Jones and Spring Mountain alongside other notable restaurants and businesses. Parking is usually very busy, so be on the lookout!  After getting situated, you'll find Ramen Tatsu tucked away at the north end of the plaza. Once inside, you are met with a quaint space with proper and kitschy Japanese decor.   The menu is easy to follow. And the food is great. I usually go with the Tonkatsu Ramen with a side of their chicken karaage. Also, beware! Their spicy levels are no joke... definitely not for the faint of heart. I love anything and everything spicy, but their special habanero peppers are no joke.

_5e_oUjY9VfedpqtoA-EFQ.text: My new fav ramen house. There's only one lady serving the whole place. She kept smiling while doing everything and is very friendly. Very tasty ramen, service was fast and reasonably priced. Would def recommend and i cant wait to go back again.

amc1ICx4csJ2BuiIPSsR9g.text: Best Ramen in Las Vegas, comparable to what I had in Tokyo!  The Tonkatsu broth is incredibly rich and complex and the thin ramen noodles done perfectly.  Very limited seating and the restaurant street signage is very hard to read.  The parking in this strip mall is inadequate at peak days and hours.  Nevertheless, it's so good, we are definitely going again!

3LQ8UxQcZv1Gy51u-SKwMw.text: Our favorite ramen restaurant by far! Not very big, but the food is the best. They have the best miso ramen in the city. The also have tsukemen, which is not easy to find here.  The restaurant is cute, with great dioramas of Japanese shops displayed in niches on the walls. Service is friendly and helpful.  I feel very conflicted about hyping this place, because I would hate for this place to become too busy and I'd have to wait for tables. But, I also want this place to be successful so it stays in business.

o1OjbBWleXXb6zJfIfhJpg.text: I use to work around the area and I would go here sometimes for the amazing customer service. The server was really nice and attentive, even when it was busy. 11cbQNweCl8y_JhNZeLmDw.text: In my quest to try every Ramen place off the strip I stopped in here for lunch. Ordered my traditional Tonkatsu Ramen with extra Chashu and an egg. Broth was nice and smooth. Chashu soft and melt in your mouth. The egg was cooked to a perfect soft boil. The noodles tasted fresh. Great place to go since Monta is so packed at peak times.

Mea-luAmEaIcTwK3qWjynQ.text: All around great. Service is really good, prices are fair. To top it off the food is delicious and the place has a great ambience. I stayed for a weekend here and came twice! Good for the hangover! Lol.

rCKtmUvIdLa9yKbYlQ21zg.text: *sigh*  That was soo good!  First time having Tsukemen Ramen and i really enjoyed it.  I asked the server what's their specialty and was kindly steered to this offering.  It's basically a combination of seafood (mackerel) and pork broth.  Those of you with shellfish allergy don't fret.  You're good, brAh!    The noodles and soup are served in separate bowls, but it is entirely up to you if you want to marry them, or be a dipper.  Have at it.  I personally recommend being a dipper because well.. it's funner!  Food just taste better when the tone is right.  Whatever it is you choose to do, don't fuck it up. I'd hate to watch you enjoy your second serving!  On its own the stock can be really dense, but perfect when pair with the noodles.  Try not to grab too much noodles as it will really pick up on the intensity of the broth.  Loads of scallions are thrown in the clump of grains and topped off with 2 piece of char-siu, a lemon wedge, and a single strip of nori.  The soup is served NOT hot, yet it is warmer than warm.  A little squeeze of lemon over the noodles and this dish actually became quite refreshing in a way.  Sodium overload?? Ain't nobody got time for that!  If you're a fan of the soba zaru (cold buckwheat noodles) then i think you'll really like Tsukemen Ramen here.  Seared Pork belly was meaty and delish!  Would order again.  Gyoza however was alright.  +1 for GOOD air circulation    *cliff* How do i come about acquiring a stamp card??
