6o4C1LRyx5skzjU06EZvXA.text: I really like it here. The food and service is consistently good. I always order miso ramen and add egg and seaweed. It is perfect portion and reasonably priced. The servers are all so nice and even though it is a fast pace place, I never feel rushed or unwelcomed. My husband always orders the deluxe ramen with the spicy miso broth. He is always sweating from the spice, but he gets it everytime so it must taste good regardless, HAHAH.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Tatsu - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Love eating here after church with my love.

p2c5_ACXMCVc20Zuf8ihSg.text: The Skinny: at the end of the meal, I had a half filled bowl of broth - 'nuff said (3), service: efficient and fast (3); value: it's okay - not too pricey for a bowl of okay ramen... but nothing that I feel like I need to return for (3 stars).  When we saw the signs for a new ramen joint opening up in the Chinatown area, we were stoked. We love ramen - tonkotsu ramen in particular - and we were very interested to find a ramen joint that serves the traditional thinner white noodles with their tonkotsu broth.  We headed over to their soft opening just to see what they had to offer. I believe that their menu is truncated a bit at this time. No matter - we decided to hit up their Tonkotsu ramen ($7.77, 2 pc chasu, green onion, ginger and woodear mushroom) and their Ramen Tatsu (basically a tonkotsu ramen with more chasu and in bigger bowl of noodles).  Okay, let me get this straight. Ramen for me is all about the broth. That is the most difficult part to get right and where all the flavor comes from in your bowl. If I am leaving a bowl of ramen with at least half a bowl of broth behind, that says something - it just ain't that good. The tonkotsu broth didn't have the luxurious porky depth that it needs to really distinguish itself from other ramen joints in the city.  On to the rest of the bowl. The chasu in the bowl didn't really have much of a marinated flavor with it and rendered it a bit bland. The noodles - although they were the legit kind - were a little too soft for my taste. I would also venture to say, the bright pink ginger topping should be left to the side instead of incorporated in the bowl. I was also a little sad that the wasn't the option of adding an egg to your bowl. Perhaps this oversight will be corrected after the soft opening.  Another thing of note was they did not have togarashi to go with the ramen - only the chili oil. As my hubs is a total togarashi fanboy, he was verily disappointed.  Service is quick and efficient. I believe we were in and out within half and hour.  Overall, in the big scheme of things, Ramen Tatsu is alright. However based on the offerings today, I don't feel a huge urge to return again soon.(3 starred review).

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Tatsu - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu ramen 7.77
Photo of Ramen Tatsu - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tatsu ramen 10.77

g25LqOCBZFTOnKhl5gYnfQ.text: I really enjoyed the tonkatsu at Ramen Tatsu. They are generous with the ingredients here and the tonkatsu was creamy and savory without the overpowering saltiness that some other ramen places serve. And man, when that bowl of ramen arrives, it's just gorgeous. Picture-perfect for all you asians, like me, who love to document their meals. Their chashu pork, although not very flavorful, is still pretty tasty. On my second visit, I got the idea to order the seared chashu and add it to my ramen. Yummy! They should totally have this option for toppings. The noodles were thinner in the tonkatsu but I didn't mind it. You probably can request the thicker noodles. A nice plus is that you can get a refill of noodles (kaedama) for only $1.50.  The restaurant is still pretty new so it has that awkward ambience of a place just starting up and the menu seems to be a work in progress. Would love to see this place do well amidst the growing number of ramen shops around town.

6zc1kxaimom2pZsXHfhlmA.text: Bf and I found our new ramen spot!!! We got a delicious meal last night and shared the restaurant with only 2 others. I got the miso ramen and my man got the tonkatsu-shoyu. I asked that the charsui be replaced with kakurage (don't eat meat) and they happily obliged :D we got the edamame to start and put some of their spicy sesame oil and soy sauce on it, delicious and not over cooked. The portions were PROPER and I couldn't recommend this place any higher! For Vday we tried Itsy Bitsy Ramen & Whiskey and were conned. The portions there were super small, so happy to have tried this place!

BFDS0y5-gSR4lsd7gZdUUw.text: Well kept secret. Never had a wait and they have kimchi and a reverse osmosis filter on their tap water. So good!

DZuOiWgBP1-YJuQuED4bWA.text: Just another Vegas restaurant with great ramen.  There's so many in town and each have their own preference, but Ramen Tatsu is definitely a good option.  This place serves their ramen a little differently where you can add the ingredients as you go rather than get a full ramen soup.  I ordered the spicy tonkatsu with added spicy sprouts and corn.  The base was actually quite spicy which is nice as most of the time I need to drench the soup in peppers or hot sauce to get a good kick.  The noodles were of the very thin variety and just ok.  The chasu was very good, with a nice line of fat for better flavor.  I'd say the broth was the best part of the meal with the chasu placing second.  The rest of the accompaniments were just average.  Not my favorite ramen in town but a True contender.  My entire meal was a little over $10 which is on the cheaper side for this dish.  I recommend trying Tatsu as it is a high quality rendition and lives up to its Vegas counterparts.

1Wv11VDrFb79WTJELmwPTQ.text: Great little local spot. Most authentic out of all the Japanese style ramen spots that are in the valley. I love how they offer True Japanese appetizers and sides. The way they boil their ramen is just like the way they do back home. Def my comfort food spot to be at when my friends are in town I love taking them here. They even offer cold ramen! Oishii

fE84sc2WviQ-MA9OC7_8Zw.text: This ramen place did not disappoint.  I ordered the Tatsu deluxe ramen and was pleasantly surprised by the thickness of the charsiu and also the flavour of the broth base. They also did not skimp on the other ingredients.  There was plenty of bean sprouts, green onion, and two pieces of nori.  The only thing they could have improved on was to give a little bit more ramen in the bowl.  Otherwise this ramen was quite delicious and I finished all the soup, which I don't usually do.  I also tried their fried rice but was not as impressed with it.  It was not flavourful enough and the presentation was not pretty.  It also had quiet a few dices of pure fat in it.  My recommendation, stick with the ramen and you will be back for more.  I give 3.5 stars.

9_gVdI_xxNenfzam-H6oHA.text: I love this ramen spot. I like my ramen spicy and they deliver! Super yummy and the service it great. The lady who works the front is bubbly and adorable. I will definitely  become a regular here.

y_acBDsvrnTMGOSqFEqJZQ.text: small but oh so worth it!! its in the small area of jones/sping mt., by Cafe Moda. limited parking. Any time my fiance has taken me its been on a fri/sat around 8pm, so i have yet to see the "late crowd". if we ever go around 11 its been during the week. but we have seen families, groups of friends and couples.  Annnnyway....staff is very very attentive and fast.   l have been to a few katsu curry places, and ramen places. this place is amazing. the tankatsu curry chicken is so dang crunchy its rediculous!!! and the gyozo is the bomb! you can make your own dipping sauce with vinegar and soy sauce on table and its just fine. the curry is thick, dark brown like gravy....yuuuummmy!!!! Rice is sticky, and they give you a LOT. they have specials, so thats great for us! My fiance gets the ramen and always orders a side of noodles for like, a dollar...and always, always regrets it...they give you a huge bowl, full of the greatest ramen noodles ever :) he always eats the food i have left on my plate,cuz i get full quick. but this little white girlie doesnt have much left for him here! i eats it allll!! haha!! The ramen bowl i think he gets is called Delux. he really likes it, and he's filipino, always getting me to try different places.   beer selection and prices are good, have specials too.   only reason i havent given 5 stars is because i actually haven't tried a ramen bowl...yet. ;)

8lC-cmXj0qL7fBypeEvgvQ.text: This place really is the only consistent ramen joint in town. I like that you know what you'll get before ordering.  Staff remains excellent despite the uptick in business. Chef/Owner, Wayne, obviously cares about the quality of his food.   The karaage is still very tasty, but there may have been a slight change to the batter. It's a little lighter than the previous version, which I preferred, but it is still a very, very good and well-seasoned karaage.  My family still includes Tatsu in our weekly restaurant rounds.

The taste... a couple of notches under montas taste, but you can't beat the fact that there is no waiting time.

DzS4ZAUHLXXKQkYgQKMJPg.text: Craving ramen and did not have any desire to sit outside and wait so came back here. 2c8pdeFKnBYSUive63OFhw.text: We came here because I received an email from Yelp recommending this place. We usually go to Monta and was pleasantly surprised with Tatsu. There's more menu choices than Monta and the restaurant is bigger. We ordered takoyaki (octopus balls -- 5 pieces $4.77) and it was absolutely yummy. I had the deluxe ramen and my husband had the curry ramen. Both ramen bowls were delicious. We're definitely coming back!

kqn1QrTpAfwxd85gFqjWVA.text: We've found another favorite ramen place! We started with appetizers: the Japanese kimchi ( which was more vinegary than the Korean kimchis I've tried),  goes very well with the smoky seared chashu. Their takoyaki comes in 4 pieces. Most of the takoyakis I've tried in other places have raw dough taste, but the ones here are  flavorful, crunchy on the outside and deliciously creamy inside, I highly recommend this.  The karaage is crispy, and even though it's fried, it's not greasy at all. The greens and refreshing  dressing that come with it complement the takoyaki & the karaage. My companion had the Shoyu ramen. The chicken broth was tasty. The egg was cooked well. The noodles were chewy in a good way. The chashu pork was buttery with just the right amount of fat.  I had the Tonkotsu ramen,which has a delicious smoky broth. It also comes with melts in your mouth chashu. Their ramen servings are huge.  Good enough for 2 people.  Service is fast and efficient. Servers are nice and friendly. Place is clean and inviting. My only wish is that they change the piped in music which rendered horrendous covers of pop music from the likes of Alicia Keys and Colbie Caillat. Other than that, this place is highly recommended. Will definitely be back. :)

yb2OAuNgjZb4p21cJ2UaIQ.text: Where their ramen falls a bit short (shoyu) compared to Monta's noodles, their side dishes ($3 happy hour prices too) edges it above Monta Chaya's efforts. Their karage is leagues better and bigger. The soup is fine but the initial toppings it comes with is a bit meager. ZBIICX6Bwe3lOZNvT2jUlQ.text: I read about Ramen Tatsu in today's Review Journal, in Wednesday's "Taste" section. I'd been craving some authentic Japanese ramen for a few days, so Mark and I thought we'd give it a try. I was really looking forward to the tonkotsu ramen. Tonkotsu is a pork based broth that is very time-consuming to make; the southern Japanese island of Kyushu is probably the capital of tonkotsu ramen, and I've had the real thing many times.  Chef Wayne Kageyama's tonkotsu did not disappoint; it was not as rich as the shiru (soup) that I became accustomed to in Fukuoka, and it had a decidedly smoky flavor that I didn't expect but was most pleasantly surprised by. The tonkotsu ramen was the only menu choice to offer the thin noodles that I prefer, and the smokiness of the broth was an excellent foil for the kimchi that I ordered extra as a topping. The very generous portion quite sated me; I had no reason or desire to order extra noodles or soup.  Mark ordered the shoyu ramen, which came with the thick noodles. The garlic chips that he ordered were a little overpowering, but the broth was delicate and not too salty at all.  We ordered a side of gyoza (better known to Americans as "pot stickers") and a side of takoyaki - small dough balls filled with pieces of octopus and topped, usually, with a sweet teriyaki type sauce, Japanese mayonnaise and shredded or powdered nori.   The gyoza were delightful; well-stuffed, fried perfectly and then quickly steamed in the pan to offer a contrast of crunch and chew. They brought back fond memories of sake-soaked late nights in mom-and-pop shops that abound in the back alleys of Osaka, trying to stave off the next morning's inevitable hangover, heh heh.   Osaka is famous for takoyaki, and unfortunately I found Tatsu's to be a small disappointment in an otherwise exceptional and very authentic meal. There was not enough octopus, and the the sauce that topped them off was almost sweet enough to make them a dessert. I must admit though, I did eat all of them!  I highly recommend this comfortable and clean restaurant for an authentic and reasonably priced adventure into Japanese cuisine. Chef Kageyama is very affable; the staff, who are all Japanese, are pleasant and efficient, and more than willing to overlook the errors in my Japanese, which has become a bit rusty of late.  The restaurant is located in a strip mall on the east side of South Jones, between Spring Mountain and Desert Inn; parking is not a problem. Beer (served ice-cold), wine, and hot and cold sake are available. Major credit cards are accepted. Dessert is conspicuously absent from the menu, but there IS a Baskin-Robbins right across the street, should you feel the need for something sweet afterward. If this review convinces you to try Ramen Tatsu out, please give a "hello" to chef Kageyama from me -the "gaijin" from Osaka!

qELcF7yifJGGYG0VYA3N4Q.text: Average 4.5 star Yelp rating?  I'm going to go against the grain and give a contrarian point of view.  Don't get me wrong, the restaurant is not so bad, just doesn't live up to the Yelp rating.  The gyoza and pork tonkatsu appetizers are pretty good.  The tonkatsu was quite moist on the inside and had a decent golden fried exterior.  Both are good choices.  The ramen broth is so so, not much depth or favor for the spicy miso ramen.  Spicy it is, but that mostly drowns out the miso broth.  The noodles are cooked perfectly, very chewy.  Portion is generous and it's a pretty good deal for $9.99.  Japanese style service which is excellent, (the restaurant is actually run by Japanese).  It's worth another try for their other broths.

I will be returning regularly as the weather cools, and I will crave their dishes again...

zXNdo4pvV1MqH6Hg214ebw.text: Slightly disappointed in the flavor of the broth, the texture of the ramen, and the overall experience of my tonkatsu ramen. I guess you can say I've been spoiled with ramen from LA and SF, so my expectations were pretty high for Ramen Tatsu. Maybe I came in on an off day because I certainly did not experience their 4.5 star reputation on yelp. The tonkatsu broth was the slightest bit tasty and wasn't fatty enough for my taste. The ramen, although generous in portion, was not al-dente but soggy as if it had been sitting in the bottom of the bowl for hours. The toppings didn't come with much: mound of green onions, two slices of cha siu,  and wood ear. I added my own egg, which was probably my favorite part of the ramen.  Nonetheless, the service was great! Green tea was perfect for a rainy night and to soothe my throat. I probably won't be coming here again with Jinya only a short drive away.

7UjutAIeVJdz3dnR_CaqNw.text: Wife was craving ramen.  Looked on Yelp--of course--and found many ramen eateries with impressive ratings.  Ramen Tatsu 4.5 rating with 400+ reviews.  Probably a safe bet, right?  Maybe by Vegas standards 4.5 but not by Hawaii standards!  Since the tone of this review started out no-so-hot, let's start with bad news.  What is wrong you ask?  The noodles and the broth!  The top two most important components of ramen!    The noodles did not have a smooth, even consistency--texture felt knotty.  Imagine a noodle that wasn't fully cooked throughout: most parts cooked but small scattered lumps uncooked.  Sorry if I'm not articulating well, in a nutshell, noodles = not good!  It didn't get any better with the broth.  =( The broth lacked depth of flavor and had zero body.  Really thin, watery broth!  It's not all bad, there is good news!  - Cheaply priced.  All menu items offered at bargain basement cost.  Hard to complain much when you aren't breaking the bank.  - Fried rice was delish!  Bowl of fried rice hit the spot!  Soo good that I didn't want to share with my wife!  LoL  Some good, some bad.  Vegas needs to step up their ramen game!

UNRwBiUmVoQmC3Pmx3PF0A.text: This is probably one of my favorite ramen place in Las Vegas! I went here with my boyfriend and the server named Shu (I think that's how it's spelled) was very friendly and kind. He was also enthusiastic and has great customer service. We asked for napkins and he gave us some and he was nice enough to give us extra just incase. He's always smiling and was always in a good mood which is great and made me and my boyfriend feel happy as well. It's amazing to have a good worker serving us and having good food. He looked like he liked his job and always did something and didn't waste his time and wasn't lazy. He comes and asks us if we were doing okay. He was very humble and I noticed he was waiting to say goodbye to us and have a good day on our way out as he was doing other things. A very great experience! Will always come back.

uDmqhUoCKg4-LqNG5elnKw.text: Real ramen made by real Japanese people! I don't want that to sound racist but hey its the truth.  This place is THE place for ramen in the valley. Having eaten a every ramen-ya in the valley, I settled for the fact that we will were forever doomed to ramen mediocrity.  The main notables for ramen in the valley do a good job filling a craving for ramen they all fail hit the spot for me.  As you can already figure out, I am a bit of a Japanese food snob as I have had the opportunity to live in the motherland for many years and made it a mission to eat many a ramen-ya and try the best ramen of many prefectures.   I am not really bias to one particular style of ramen and usually default to the respective Ramen-ya's specialty.  For this place they had a nice array of ramen types from traditional miso and shoyu to curry ramen.    We opted to try one mild (miso) and one wild (curry).  I chose the curry ramen as I am a fan of curry udon so this was right up my alley. I enjoyed this bowl however it didn't blow my mind: it was "different" . The curry flavor was very subtle and ended up getting washed away with the base broth and eventually was lost.I think I will stick to curry udon and 86 the ramen variant.   The Miso Ramen was the champ here! The base was very sweet and rich and at first bite transported me back to the motherland. Ensure that your order this with corn, butter and garlic: The REAL way to enjoy miso ramen.  Butter you say? Don't knock it until you rock it. I mean if it wasn't good why would they have it on the menu? And besides that's how we do it in the motherland..  Take it from me this place does miso ramen legit!! This is now my default for my ramen fix in the Vegas Valley.   Eat with confidence   -P

Photo of Ramen Tatsu - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso ramen Be sure to add corn, garlic and butter

gxJyN4Pw7vJmahU0VQ54xA.text: My new favorite ramen obsession!   I don't know why it's taken me forever and a day to eat here. Usually when I go to a ramen place, I measure them by their gyoza and their miso ramen. I actually haven't tried the miso ramen yet here because I've been getting their delicious tsukemen! Their version has a strong fish flavor and reminded me of David Chang's Mind of A Chef where he looks into making bonito in Japan. Their egg is perfectly soft-boiled and the chasu served cold is thick and full of flavor. The noodles are extra thick, firm, and flatter than your normal ramen noodle in order to increase surface area for dipping. My husband has ordered the tonkatsu shoyu, which also has a fishy taste. He enjoyed it and his leftovers were still delicious the next day, which I attribute to the noodles holding up very well. As far as sides go, the gyoza meat was a bit dry, so I probably wouldn't order that again, but the curry rice and the side salad are satisfying and filling. The kimchi fried rice isn't too spicy, which I liked, but may be a turn-off for those who want kimchi fried rice from a Korean restaurant. Their iced green tea is not canned or bottled, which is an extra plus for me. It's only $1.77 too with free refills! (a lot of their pricing ends in .77 cents). To top it all off, they have two TVs that are angled strategically for maximum viewing pleasure and the servers here handle their business efficiently and are very helpful/friendly. I'll be back for more :D

zOEOZxdtcZyN_jbEm_YYIw.text: Finally, we found Ramen Tatsu! I swear, it was like finding Waldo. I'm not going to blame my poor vision on having missed the sign the first time I attempted to visit. Its signage can easily be missed. Just look for District One and you'll eventually spot Ramen Tatsu.  When we arrived, the restaurant was surprisingly empty on a Saturday around dinnertime, but it was nice having the place to ourselves. I ordered the Tonkotsu and my boyfriend ordered the Spicy Miso. By the way, the marinated soft boiled egg doesn't come with the ramen. It's an additional $1 charge for an item commonly free at other ramen restaurants.   Tonkotsu Ramen - The broth had a meaty flavor. Noodles were firm, thin, and cooked well. Pork was fatty, fat, fat. The green onions were on the heavy side.  Spicy Miso - Unless you want to feel more heat, there's no need for additional red pepper. If you've had the spicy miso at Jinya, this is comparable to theirs.   Being the only diners in the restaurant, service was quick and we received our hot bowls of ramen in an instant.   The food is decent, and we didn't pay over $10 for each of our orders.

MHXgvW1jxa_JAemPz2qhQw.text: My boyfriend and I were recently introduced to this place by a couple of good friends and let's just say... I'm throwing up 5 stars!  My friend is a huge fan of tsukemen ramen (known as cold ramen). Now if you're not familiar with this... It's basically ramen noodles separated from the soup. You pick up your portion size of noodles and dip it into the soup. The noodles are a lot fatter, almost resembling pasta noodles and the soup is a lot more thick.   *There aren't many ramen places that serve this on Vegas. She's a fan because she's from California and they serve this a lot there!*  The broth was delicious and the taste was delightful. I don't know how else to explain it. You have to go and try it for yourself. I will advise tho that even I had to trade out my chopsticks for a fork because my noodles kept slipping.  Let me add that this place doesn't get overly packed! It's a consistent flow of business, but I'm sure you won't find yourself waiting to be seated.

8yPrJlB6Kq-v-G-mvVhpAw.text: Decent-enough ramenya on the outskirts of Chinatown- broth isn't as fatty as other places, which may appeal to others who feel that Sora et al are too rich for their tastes.  Went in with my BF and split the deluxe tonkotsu-shoyu, the house specialty per Tetsuro. Deluxe bowl comes decked out with all of the extra veggies and meat: four slices of chashu, nori, an egg, green onion, sprouts, corn, cabbage, and bamboo shoots. Also added on orders of edamame, karaage, and lychee sorbet.  Broth was understated but still had good depth, and the various toppings and giant bowl made it a more than generous portion for two, well-priced at just under $11. Egg was a little overcooked, which is  a ramen pet peeve of mine and I also didn't care for the corn or overwhelming amount of cabbage.   Karaage was moist and I really enjoyed the light breading. Squeezed some lemon over it for an extra perk of acidity.  Sorbet was a great palate cleanser with a pop of flavor, larger portion than what is given gratis at Ramen Misoya Tomi.   Wouldn't put this in my top ramen picks for Vegas, but wouldn't turn down a visit if a friend suggested it, either.

uc1-Z1EIElLoBTzA4VfTCA.text: It seems like there's a new ramen place keep popping up in Vegas lately.  "Ramen Tatsu" has been around for about couple of years now, and my recent visit was my first time there.  I had a Japanese buddy of mine from San Francisco Bay Area visiting during the CES convention, and we usually go to a ramen place at least once during his visit.  This time we went to Tatsu and we were very pleased.  My buddy's name is "Tetsu" so, I remembered to go to "Tatsu."  We started with some beer and chicken kara-age (Japanese style chicken nuggets) and some pot stickers.  The pot stickers were good, but, no different than any other good ramen places. I can probably pan fry those pot stickers a little better than they can.  Kara-age was crispy outside and moist inside.  Perfect!  That shows me they're very good in deep frying.  Then we ordered our main.  My buddy ordered the "Tsukemen"  It's a thick ramen that almost look like udon noodles which comes with two types of dipping sauce.  I'm not much of a fan of eating ramen dipping it in a sauce.  I'd rather do that with a cold udon or soba.  However, those dipping sauces were delicious.  I ordered the Deluxe ramen that comes with extra slices of  cha-shu.  I can tell the cha-shu is home made, and sliced thicker than you usually see at a ramen place.  Those cha-shu were very tender and flavorful with not too much fat.  The noodle was firm and very well done, the way I like it.  Toppings were similar to the stuff I use when I make my own ramen, so, not surprised there.  Tonkotsu-Shoyu (Soy sauce based pork broth) soup was also, excellent.  Very rich broth, not oily, nor salty.  Very authentic Japanese ramen soup.  Tonkotsu-Shoyu ramen originated in Yokoyama (Kanagawa Prefecture) and, has been popular in the Kanto region (Seven eastern prefectures including Tokyo).  Tonkotsu (pork bone) ramen is basically, a traditional ramen in Kyushu.  It's like a mixture of both, Shoyu ramen of Kanto with tonkotsu ramen of Kyushu.  Tonkotsu-Shoyu ramen noodles are the regular curly ramen noodles rather than the straight thin type normally used in the Kyushu or "Hakata style" ramen.  On the scale of 1 to 10, I would give this ramen a 9.  It would've been a 10 if the cha-shu was properly seared on the outside.  The word "cha-" of "cha-shu" comes from the Chinese "chaasiu" or "char siu" which means "barbequed" or "seared" pork.  Obviously, ramen was invented by a Chinese cook in Japan, unclear of when, but, some historians say about 350 years ago; hence it uses the naming from Chinese words, and uses both Chinese and Japanese style of cooking.  At least I know it's been around for more than a century, and became popular in the 1950s.  Now I've got a place to go for Tonkotsu-Shoyu ramen!

qxD-MpXW8eEGr8JNBoxY-A.text: Recently I was invited to a dinner which featured several of the most famous Las Vegas Japanese restaurant owners. It was unanimous in their opinion that they believed RAMEN TATSU was the best TOKYO RAMEN-YA in America. Yes, you heard that statement correctly. TATSU is NOT a Kyushu Ramen-Ya, it is a TOKYO style Ramen-Ya that specializes in Shoyu style broth. If you don't believe me, ask the owner himself. The owners name is Wayne and he is a very respected man in the LV Japanese-American community.   RAMEN TATSU is unique in the fact that all ingredients are natural/organic style. Wayne uses three different types of natural chicken bones for the broth in his Tokyo style ramen. He also uses three different types of natural pork bones for his Tonkotsu ramen. No other ramen-ya in Las Vegas goes this far out of their way to produce such a rich broth. Many Japanese yelpers express that the reason California(Sawtelle Blvd) ramen is so much better than LV ramen is because the California places use this style of cooking. The cook and owner has been the force behind many of the popular ramen-yas in Los Angeles. He was the man responsible for the recipes which have now achieved notoriety, the same recipes from the LA ramen-yas that attended this years Ramen festival at the Rio Casino.   The signature dish at RAMEN TATSU is the Shoyu-Tonkotsu fusion. This variation of ramen has become increasingly popular in modern day Japan. It's origins stem from the Kobe area, where it has become a new subregional variation of ramen. On account of the fact that Wayne is from Kobe, he has many years of experience preparing this subregional variation.  The recipe at TATSU remains unchanged from the recipe from Kobe while Monta's Shoyu-Tonkotsu is not the authentic recipe, instead it is merely an invention of the Kurume cook(who is now a Brazilian dude), who mixes his Kyushu broth with a generic nonaffiliated shoyu broth. What I am expressing is that RAMEN TATSU has the only authentic Shoyu-Tonkotsu in LV. And, this is the item you should order during your next visit.    The Curry- During your next visit at RAMEN TATSU, you should not neglect the Japanese Curry. TATSU uses their own secret recipe which facilities a unique taste which upon my assessment is superior to CoCo Ichinbanya and Kaba Curry. In a demonstration of unique cooking styles, the Chicken broth from the ramen is used as the backing for the curry. Wayne's own particular Gram Masala is then instilled into the broth, and combined with three different types of vegetables. The resulting product is curry that is as addictive as Mr. Zenbayashi's recipe. And during a recent conversation with Mr. Zenbayashi, even he verbally approved of Wayne's recipe. That is a major compliment coming from the man who runs the highest rated Curry-Ya in yelp history.   They also have Shio Ramen which is great for older Japanese folks. A lot of older Japanese people like my Dad refuse to eat Tonkotsu and Miso Ramen, and eat nothing but Shio.   I will argue that RAMEN TATSU is the most authentic Japanese Ramen-Ya in America. It remains True to the regional recipes in Japan, and the owner refuses to submit to western pressures to "Americanize" his recipes(as you can see, many of the negative reviews are due to the fact that the recipe is not americanized). For example, Wayne recently terminated contracts with noodle suppliers because he felt they were not completely authentic to Japanese standards. For the last few weeks, several Japanese noodle companies have been competing for the contract, while Wayne assesses and samples them all to determine which is the most appropriate. The whole reason that Tsukemen is no longer on the menu is because Wayne demanded his distributors send noodles which were 100% authentic to the dish and made in Japan. He would not accept anything lower, and would NEVER serve an item that wasn't 100% authentic to the traditional Japanese recipe. Tsukemen will return shortly from my understanding. This establishment represents the Japanese culture very proudly and will not give into the pressures to westernize the menu. This is the reason there is no Togarashi. This is the reason there is no Srirachi. This is the reason why there is no cans of Pabst Blue Ribbon. Just like the owner of Kabuto, Wayne won't breech protocol which was established in Japan by the Japanese, for the Japanese. And I respect him a lot for this. Complaining that there is no  Shichimi Togarashi at a ramen-ya is like bitching to the chef at Kabuto about why there is no California rolls while you soak your chutoro nigiri in a mixture of shoyu and wasabi that you plan on eating with a fork. I have to say that I vouch for RAMEN TATSU and encourage all the Japanese-American residents of LV to support this business.   Just a final note- The music they play here is the theme music to the Final Fantasy games, and old school anime like Cutey Honey, Candy Candy, and the Miyazaki films

I guess they had to fry it so it took longer.   The service was pretty great, but I'm the type of person that likes piping hot food, so the cold items turned me off.

GN6ZasfrE6Z35-MujlioDA.text: Food was great and the server was really nice and friendly. Portions are generous and the ramen was really good and comforting.

oKczuruE7lLW4u47eR2UpA.text: Decided to give this place a try after a friend recommended it. Had a girls lunch, ordered seared chasiu, gyoza, spicy tonkatsu ramen and kimchi fried rice. I'm not really a fan of spicy food, but my friends are and they said that the soup was really spicy but edible so be wary. Better to have it regular and add your own level of spice. Overall price was adequate for quality and amount of food. Everything was served hot and fresh. The service was provided by the owner herself, she was friendly and quick to refill drinks and check in on us. We came during the happy hour special which starts at 3pm. It wasn't too busy, which made it a perfect spot for my girls and I to chat. The environment was clean and open.   Definitely recommend and will return.

KKLM4TDfPiWEsH98b5EWBw.text: Best place for Ramen in Vegas!  Such a cute place and very authentic. Food is amazing. Service is great-she is so sweet!  Will come back again and again!

v1CHKSVaHF3FL-tdovCzNA.text: Been to many Ramen places. In town, and out of town (travel for work) and I gotta say that I love this place!  When I lived in CA I would travel from the Bay Area to Sacramento for Shoki House (their first location), and sometimes to New Tokyo Ramen in Marina, but Ramen Tatsu is awesome. So happy this place is local for me.  I heard about a few other ramen places in town that people rave about, but the wait times were long, service below average and the ramen tasted like it was quickly prepared and lacked anything that made it stand out.  Ramen Tatsu takes care of you.   Friendly staff.  Been here 5 times now and will continue to come. I don't think they've remembered me yet but each time they're kind, attentive and generous. This place has even given us some of their iced green tea to take home and catered to our 'not a lot of time but really wanted ramen' needs when we needed to rush an order. They rushed it right through by serving two cups of our tea, the check right after food and our second order of noodle right on time while still keeping is from feeling like we were being a bother or like we were just a quick dollar for them.   Great food.  Again, top notch ramen in Vegas. Maybe the 'other' ramen joint that people rave about (starts with an M;) was great in the past, but the last few times I've gone it's been average/good, not great and definitely not as good as Ramen Tatsu.  I've narrowed my go-to bowl as the Shoyu with an extra egg and extra noodle mid way through. My girlfriend enjoys the Spicy Tonkotsu with an egg. It's definitely spicy. Two scoops of hers on my Shoyu change things up enough for me.  She's had to extra spicy miso too, but enjoys the Tonkotsu more so.   Price is awesome. We both eat for less than $30 and that includes extra noodles, extra eggs, edemame, two iced green teas (these are delicious), and green tea mochi ice cream. All on top of our two bowls of ramen.   All in all, I rank it up their for Ramen joints. I'll be back, many....many more times.

gRPjG1LFrF0gpO-J2HuuAQ.text: Ramen Tatsu is great! I heard about it from a coworker who recommended it for ramen lovers like myself. The service is great here! Although there was only one server, she had great energy & was very attentive with all her tables. The ramen soup portions are pretty big so expect to come out feeling full & satisfied! The menu is simple & offers several different options. It also offers separate topping options for your choice of ramen. The environment is cozy & the decor is simple. The crafted decor caught my eye, it reminded me of the crafted decor from Colombia, full of detail! I will definitely be coming back here soon. Its on my side of town & it has left me wanting more!

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Tatsu - Las Vegas, NV, United States

emFGx0yAlBA8wupTUapnww.text: I ordered the spicy miso ramen w/ egg, which was amazingly delicious!! The Asian female server was super friendly and efficient. :) My hubby ordered the small curry rice, gyoza & chicken Karaage. The only reason why I didn't rate this place the perfect five stars was because my piece of the chicken Karaage had a chunk of fat in it - EWWWW!!

h41yDj2PrHp2hU37MD0MLQ.text: Don't know why this place only has a 3.5 stars. It deserves way better rating than 3.5. I was skeptical to go here as first since I'm a big fan of Monta and Sora. And after trying the fusion ramen place, which was a pretty big disappointment, I thought I should just stay with what I know and go with the popular places. But after reading one reviewer's detailed description on how True the owner is on ingredient and style at the place, I figured I'd give it a try.   And now I think I don't ever have to go to Monta anymore, especially Monta is pretty much a guarantee to stand in line kind of place.  It's a cute little place run by real Japanese folks. The Japanese lady who took our order is so cute and attentive. If you check in on yelp you can get a free drink, ice green tea included.   They have many variety of ramens, just like other ramen places. The pork is perfect in between Monta and Sora. I always think the pork at sora is too big and fatty, and pork at Monta is too thin and a bit stingy. Pork here is perfect size and they have regular size noodles and thin noodles, just depends on what type of ramen you get. And their egg is perfectly cooked. The yoke is to perfection.   Their karaage is THE BEST I've ever had. Meaty, perfect crispness without too much breading and not oily at all.  You must order it when you go.   I really don't need to go stand in line at Monta for my ramen fix anymore!!

YTPW3lbZD74Y3VuzjlD9Ww.text: Might be my new go to ramen place. Favors are comparable to the other big name ramen joints in town. I like selection of cooked foods they have. Kimchi fried rice is a plus. Try the curry ramen if you're looking for something new. Haven't tried the shio or Miso but the tonkotsu is good.

YD02rAUA5Li8JUvz7INwIQ.text: I just went there yesterday with my boyfriend, it was our second visit. We both ordered TONKATSU SHOYU with thick noodles. Personally I'm not a fan of thin noodles,so the thick noodles were perfect for me (mind that as far as asian noodles go, the THICK NOODLE is on the thin-medium to medium range).  It doesn't come with many ingredients but that's what I love about it, simple and delicious. You can always side order additional toppings of your choice. The broth is dense and full of flavor, though it might be a bit salty. The meat was cooked right, I enjoyed my ramen with a carefully selected and prepared chasiu :)  The decor of the restaurant is very nice, simple and not flashy. I got to have my dinner in the slow flow of jazz, I can imagine myself bringing my laptop and books here to work, but that would be inappropriate lol. Overall, I love this restaurant, very relaxed environment.

LxPpedDjhbwEOBGiDF3Wqg.text: Very rich noodle soup. They shorted me on noodle soup so that they can charge extra for extra soup refill, which I thought it was a little shady. But overall good Ramen.

_RdzBW9q1ZCPJZCG2UCvGA.text: One of the best ramen places I have been to hands down.  They make the noodles fresh right in front of you.  If you love spicy they can make you cry,  if you love mild you will delight in sumptuous and quality food and service.

9KjMTQIJxGlTwZ7LmhD2ig.text: We love, love, love ramen in our family. We have five people in our family and we all ordered a different ramen dish. Everyone loved what they ordered. That is hard to come by in a family of five. Super impressive!! Prices are great as well. Our server was amazing. We will definitely be there often. You should try this place for sure. You will not be disappointed.

pvBgtNH39GQSq4-iqIL9cw.text: Tried this place out after seeing a review.  I went a little early in the evening so only two tables were occupied.  So understandably the service was attentive.  The place has two TV which happened to have the evening baseball game on, so that was an unexpected plus for me. I got the most popular dish on the menu, as recommended by the server.  And a side of pot stickers.  The ramen was great, with a good amount of pork and veggies.  The broth had loads of flavor and the noodles were done perfectly.  I thought the pot stickers were good, but nothing great. It had a nice simple, not too cluttered, interior.  Will definitely go back!

Wpy_UR-2ZiPBcF4cI3mbPA.text: Awesome place for ramen. The spicy shoyu is my favorite. Great customer service short wait for your food. I have brought different groups of friends here and most agree that the food is very authentic and delicious. Will be back again and again and again.

BJCFeYDUcBCBJWOAMrCXcw.text: This place used to be a 5/5 about a year ago. Something has changed. The broth just isn't as flavorful anymore. It's still alright, but it's way behind the top 3 in Chinatown (Ramen Sora, Monta, & Jinya)

Y8wqLylW3xLLsyzoMOc6-A.text: I was excited to have some ramen in Vegas but I was disappointed in this spot. My ramen came out and it looked like it was missing some more broth. I understand that there's an option to purchase more broth but I didn't even have enough broth to warm up both of my COLD chasu or egg. Chasu was good and tender but they sliced it thinly AND gave only 2 pieces in my miso ramen. The egg was not really as flavorful in comparison to other places. On a good note, my thick ramen noodles were good and the texture was just right. Service was good just the food wasn't as good as I had hoped for.

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Tatsu - Las Vegas, NV, United States

7B18tzocu73TIOppAeYocQ.text: This is by far my favorite ramen spot in town. Feels so cozy and comfortable to eat here. I love the shio ramen, medium spicy with a passion, it is my absolute favorite. I have tried other ramen here, but I usually go back to shio every time. The takoyaki is really good as an appetizer and I love the cute macaroons filled with ice cream for dessert. The deluxe ramen is so delicious, but you've got to have a huge appetite to be able to eat it all. The fact that I can have a hot green tea or a Sapporo with my ramen is just the icing on the cake. Love this place.

u8-Hgu8fIQswcbtQSbeSZw.text: This place is a ramen heaven!!! Everything is spot on here-the service, the food, the atmosphere, everything!! We were a group of 5 tired and hungry people and were all beyond happy with the overall experience here. The server was very friendly and helped us with the order. Never did she fail to smile and made sure that our glasses were filled to the brim at all times!! Though it was pretty late (almost toward the closing time) on a weekday, the quality of food and service didn't lack a thing. The spicy miso ramen couldn't be any better. Have had so many ramen all around the country, and this to me, is one of the bests. If you like your ramen spicy, spicy miso is the ramen for you. The tonkatsu ones are scrumptious as well. The broths were creamy (but not too much), keeping it just perfect and they all tasted awesome. My sister in law loved their fried rice as well. Oh, don't forget to order their takoyaki; it was aaammaazing! I would definitely be back here whenever I'm visiting the area.

o8uGFSzhUayJkzgfPxdu_Q.text: I had them remake my ramen and the noodles were still uncooked, and i told the server about it and she said "I don't think so." I was like okay?. And the whole restaurant smelled like pee. Never again. Worst ramen i have ever had.

rKgimgAfju9WXUhGGlk4lA.text: I got the Deluxe and it was simply mediocre. The broth was too salty and the chasiu was very tender but it was sour. Overall it was okay if you just are desperate for some ramen but I probably won't go again.

Qh6pEnlsByKNMkBxg78CUg.text: Authentic Japanese ramen place! I'd say it's best in Las Vegas. I wish katsu came with the curry & rice. However, still the best!

hPpCET29AeIy4rnv1gcubg.text: Ramen here is so good but I think if they're have make by your own It's gonna be good too. I recommend just 1 Ramen with 1 App you will be full. Lol.

pxY8G-n2qni24GXEULcPYQ.text: I'm Asian.  I'm from Hawaii.  I eat a lot of ramen.  And this is GOOD ramen.  All in good fun and no harm meant...  This really is great noodles and pork broth. I hear the owner brings in Sun noodles from Hawaii.  The ramen noodle is thin, soft yet firm, holds its own taste while holding the flavor of the broth very well.  The broth is rich and flavorful.   I've had the spicy miso ramen, chicken curry, spicy tonkatsu ramen, and tsukemen.  All, very lovely.  I don't say this too often while traveling, this is a must eat if you are looking for ramen worth eating.    Service is well done.  They were very accommodating with us, a large group filled with hungry children.  Food was brought out quickly.  Its a tiny place, yet provides a comforting and welcoming ambiance.

jqimwX-bLtEby_YTQ0oK8w.text: Its good to see that Las Vegas is finally getting a good selection of ramen houses. Ramen Tatsu was recommended by a friend who frequents this place and I have to agree that they offer one of the better tasting ramens in Vegas. The ramen shop is quaint, tightly packed (just like most authentic Japanese ramen houses), and run by very pleasant people. We ordered the spicy tonkotsu, shoyu ramen, takoyaki and kimchi rice and weren't disappointed by the flavors and serving portions. The ramen noodles were cooked perfectly, not soggy nor was it undercooked. The broths were delicious and had very satisfying umami flavors. If I had any gripe it would just be the smaller than usual sized takoyakis (down from the golfball-sized ones I'm used to), which had tastiness that made up for the lack of portions. I'm sure me and wifey will now include this spot as part of our ramen rotations, especially now that our usual go-to places are always packed to the brim. But make no mistake, Ramen Tatsu isn't just a substitute ramen place, it's now a must-eat there place!

photos.caption: Photo of Ramen Tatsu - Las Vegas, NV, United States

hcsSilOma9oIb86dXxD_hQ.text: Love the service and vibe! Japanese bar vibe, great ramen great price and also best tsukemen in town! I been coming here for 3 years and never a let down. Clean spot and awesome happy hour!

RYgR2XjyjEaK3wtfmq5qCw.text: This place is amazing and prices are great! I found home!!! I have been trying to find a place that serves amazing Japanese ramen and I have. Everyone must come here!

hEuRyR-hA9dek_paNpBTIA.text: One of the best ramen bowls I've ever had. We came shortly after the lunch hour so we didn't have to wait and got seated immediately. The restaurant was cool in the hot summer sun. I'm thankful for great service who gave us our drinks immediately. The ramen was broth was extremely flavorful and delicious. The noodles were chewy and soft.

P5Fc-FeE4j8mwP9lVjEodg.text: Wanted to try out a new ramen place in the spring mountain area and found this place on Yelp. Really enjoyed the Soyou ramen from here. The restaurant is a bit small and I can image it can be very busy during lunch times. It wasn't that bad when we got there for dinner as there were tables available. For a bowl of Soyou Ramen for $7.77, that's a good deal. Also should add that the bathrooms were clean. That's a plus lol! Definitely will come back here with friends.

hJuu0l646yYjyhLnYXKpmA.text: One of my favorite places in town. Authentic and quality. Cute and quaint location, friendly service not sure what else you could really ask for. Ooooh I forgot to mention the best part  Asahi happy hour 3-6. On weekdays!   :) good stuff.

R5HH02dIBDzFyH3wfBpJ0Q.text: Spice made me feel like I was back in hungdea in my fav little ramen house. For sure will be back next bring the gf and kid so they know what real ramen is like

mQCNHNb8D_w1ZW9LzJ1ncA.text: Loved this place. Ambiance great. Mama San so friendly   Prices reasonable. Ramen so delicious and gyoza was tops!    Happy hour prices which start at 3 great!

AJZKzAkNodQN1MXYFI708Q.text: Best ramen I've ever had! Was visiting from California and happened to find this spot and went twice during the week that I stayed in Vegas. Quality of the food is good and so is the customer service. Every waitress we got was so sweet. Can't wait to come back.

HiJim5p_jSB5qiZjugpzEA.text: Our new fav ramen place, definitely coming back here if we visit Vegas again. They have a small portion menu for the kids. Their broth & noddle is bomb!

u4PiDbrw4fvwwrc24wuerg.text: WHAT A GEM!!!  My sister, cousin & I were looking for some great options off the strip & thankfully we found a Matcha place in the same plaza as this restaurant & decided to go there before our dessert. THE BEST MOVE EVER!!!  I ordered the Veggie ramen (be aware the noodles have some egg in it, I believe) & my sister had the veggie egg rolls & rice, my cousin had shomai (I'm sorry if I spelled it wrong) & rice. WE DEVOURED EVERYTHING. My sister loved my ramen dish & will order that next time. It was so rich, savory, & filling. It was really just what I needed since I was getting over a cough. It did make me hot & made my nose run, BUT I DON'T CARE! It was that good.  There is so many great other businesses located in the same plaza. It's packed with various other Asian owned businesses, which look to be thriving. So, you can get tons of errands run & taken care of in one spot.  Oh! And to make it even better, we had the DOPEST waitress was the SHIZ & her name happens to be Shizuka (which means, "SHUT UP!") HAHAHA!!! She is the best! We loved her energy, she made some great suggestions, & she was FUNNY AF!!!  Come for the food & come back for the food & service, YOU WILL NOT REGRET IT.

Photo of Ramen Tatsu - Las Vegas, NV, United States

fhshk7bhEB9wazKNbwqQrA.text: Brrrrrr!! This Vegas weather has got me craving some goood ramen. I can finally check this place off my bookmark list. What I love most about this place is it's Japanese authenticity. You walk in, get greeted, with plenty of seating area available. I've had ramen in Japan and this place come preeeeeetty close to the ramen shops in Japan.  Me and my boyfriend got the takoyaki & shrimp shumai to start. Takoyaki was fresh and warm, crispy on the outside and creamy on the inside. One thing I wish they served on top of this is bontio flakes! Shrimp shumai was steamed and also very tasty. Both great appetizers to start off with.  I had the tonkatsu shoyu and my boyfriend got the deluxe ramen. If you like tonkatsu broth I'd highly recommend trying this... the shoyu brings out a little more flavor of the tonkatsu and isn't too salty. The noodles had a perfect texture (I hate when its super mushy & soft). Servings are pretty generous and prices are very affordable to other ramen spots in town.   The only downside about this place is parking.... be prepared to drive around the lot a few times although I did see some people parked the across the street.

Photo of Ramen Tatsu - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Dessert menu

S06wsS9M35pkGH6fZQfuXA.text: My girlfriend and I come here all the time, and it's our favorite place to get Ramen :)  I always get a Medium Spicy - Shoyu and my girlfriend gets Spicy Miso Ramen without Ground Pork. Gyoza and fried rice is also great!  Service is always fast and friendly.

pYkqD3m7GOLBjaBgc33B9Q.text: Really great ramen. A huge selection of other offerings. Gyoza, takoyaki, tonkatsu. You want it they got it.   I tried the tonkatsu and thought it was really good.   We ordered the gyoza and they took a little longer to come out. The skin was super thin and it was really well crimped, but the bottoms was a little too charred for my taste.   When it comes to ramen, I tried the tsukemen and the veggie ramen. The tsukemen is a bonito/miso base. The broth was a little thinner than I've had in the past for dipping noodles. It was still good, but not my favorite.   The veggie ramen was really good! I think I actually preferred it to the tsukemen (although their chasu is really good). Veggie broth was full and flavorful.   Service was great. Food was great. What else could you ask for?

385R6Wzkq3uhNqGvMqjnSw.text: I was visiting the area, looking for apartments and a friend suggested that we try this restaurant. It looks like a typical Japanese restaurant walking in, with that Japanese decor and vibe. We were seated immediately and placed our order. I ordered the tonkotsu ramen with extra chasu. The broth was decent, nothing too special. The meat was flavorful, soft and very good. I also ordered the karage as an appetizer and it was good, but tasted like any other place.

4ti4z_7AC-n-EJ6N6ruwkg.text: I was referred to this place by a local, and it definitely did not disappoint!  The wait was almost non-existent.  It was a great place for a casual, cozy experience.  The meat in the shoyu ramen was so tender!  The saltiness for the ramen was perfect - NOT undersalted OR oversalted.  If anything, I was disappointed with the gyoza.  This was rather bland by itself and needed some uplifting flavors.  That being said...I'd still give this five stars for how great the ramen was.

t60BJw_zXDa00T7jcPkugw.text: 10/22/18 Dinner with the whole fam...this is my 2nd time here. We opt to come here due to Jinya had a 40 minute wait for a party of 7. We called this place and was told there is no wait time so we quickly got into our cars and zoomed on over. Sure enough there were a few open tables.  We ordered a few Ramen dishes, curry katsu, fried rice, soboro bowl ( marinated groundbeef and eggs) and shumai. All was to our taste and liking. Food was made quickly. Typical Ramen place with rice dishes to the menu and sides. I'd return if in the area. Happy eats!!

qI4lV8NNwuGw3XLSMn6Q6w.text: Love this place! Everything was excellent. Good beer, food was great and service was awesome.

60zjSc39uykoc3HMCQaLXQ.text: Mediocre ramen and terrible service. The broth was pretty bland and lacked richness and depth. I was able to make it better with lots of chili pepper and some fried garlic chips (+$1). The chashiu and the takoyaki was good though, but not good enough to make me forget about the bad service.   A member of our party ordered extra chashiu, but didn't receive it (we thought, because we asked for it on the side). The server said the chef put it into the soup. She then walked over, leaned over our table and proceeded to point (with her fingers practically in the bowl) and count each piece of meat in my friend's bowl as he was eating. We had other issues with the food/service during our meal and the staff handled each of them terribly.

OIgtlaLFqH4ak1AV7Xab9w.text: Ramen Tatsu is a tiny whole in the wall that serves up a legit bowl ramen. The service here is extremely friendly! I loved the vibe. My bowl of Miso Ramen came out piping hot (nothing is worse than a luke warm bowl of ramen), very spicy as I requested (they don't skimp on the spice) and was delicious. The egg was cooked perfectly and the noodles were nice and al dente. That being said, somehow I prefer the taste of the noodles at Monta Ramen. My husband and friend got the Shoyu Ramen and they both said the taste was unique and good. Gyozas were pretty good but I would pass on the shrimp shumai.

9adj5b-7BpeYcWdpYQPfIg.text: I usually come to Tatsu for their Tsukemen specifically and every single time it was on point. Except for today... unfortunately the Tsukemen broth wasn't thick at all, it was barely sticking onto the noodles. The broth was seasoned poorly. I'm honestly not sure if they didn't add enough bonito but it basically tasted like lightly salted tap water. My friend and I both asked for new broth explaining how it didn't taste the same, and the waitress was happy enough to comply to our request. The second broth came out and it tasted the same, if not worse lol. Being one of the few ramen places in Vegas i'm really disappointed with what happened.  Sad to say i'll be taking my business elsewhere for Ramen until they bring back their old Tsukemen recipe!

3An421dn3r20J_p_FpwFTQ.text: I was having ramen craving during my last trip to Vegas and I came across this small ramen shop.   Here is the breakdown.  Menu- one star  Good menu options with some variety in the ramen selection together with some nice small dishes with pretty authentic flavor and taste to it. Went there twice and order two different type of ramen and had a good time eating them. Also, ordered some sides and it was pretty good.   Decor/ ambiance- one star   Very traditional location with a very casual feel to it. Laid back decor that reminds those Japanese's interior design.   Service- one star  The staff was very friendly and nice. Always attentive and very fast which I definitely appreciate it.  Wow factor- no star   Missing that wow factor. Ramen was good but not the best I had.   Overall- one star  Had a good experience and would definitely come back next time I am in Vegas.

rbmIO1Ih5adRVxKejMdkVg.text: I'm quite biased when it comes to ramen joints but I'm glad I came here, I didn't come here for the tonkotsu ramen giant, so i'll save that for another review.  Ramen Tatsu exceeded my expectations,  they're the only place I know that serves Tsukemen ramen, this availability took my obsession for ramen to another level. If you're unfamiliar with Tsukemen Ramen, it's popularity has grown over the years, and one of the most notable concept of ramen as a regional style, is that it is undressed and the cold noodles are dipped into an accompanying bowl of fishy, undiluted broth before slurping. do not expect a traditional bowl of ramen swimming in a sea of broth. This makes for a great dish during the hot summer months of Las Vegas. I opted to add a few toppings to my noodles as well. RT's sweet, spicy, citrusy broth clinging to extra-fat tsukemen noodles (Not udon) Has introduced to another dimension of ramen like no other, Move over everyone! Ramen tatsu's Tsukemen has staked its claim in the noodle pantheon of sin city. Have no mercy!

w25-3mlxRg520u0WJGVZAw.text: Had the Tonkatsu ramen, with 2 eggs and garlic chips. The garlic chips are a must have topping! Would recommend coming back

i59A1qSBiSjy_EI-eiMCBg.text: So far, the tastiest ramen I've had in Vegas.  Compared to Monta and Sora, I feel like their broth isn't as salty which I enjoyed. I tried the miso ramen which had plenty of flavor. The waitress was so genuinely friendly and smiley which I always appreciate. The interior is really clean and the cover music is real mellow. Great spot for quick ramen. Will be back again!

owrnhH0J37oJJTvOXxsUMg.text: I had high hopes for this joint, but fell short a bit...  Upon entering you may think looks similar to *onta, that's cuz the same contractor built it!  Ambiance looks good, smells good, tastes good, but needs a bit of color or pizazzz in the bowl.  I just don't feel the magic...  The green onions were the only vibrant add on in my spicy tonkatsu ramen.  The broth itself was good n porky, habanero infusion adds a kick to the tastebuds!  When it comes to any Japanese cuisine, I have come to expect the visual sensations as well as the palate sensations to come together in a harmonious combination of flavor and flair.  I know....sounds like a food snob but truth be told!  Imagine a California roll with no red crab, no green avo, just white rice n black seaweed, still look appetizing?  Back to the ramen, maybe add some red daikon? Shredded carrot? Cucumber leaf?  Fish cake swirly thing? An habanero slice? (no seeds!)  I'm no chef, but I know what looks and tastes good!  Ima give em another shot but on to the next...  *iromaru here I come  Try every Ramen joint in Vegas?   Challenge accepted!!!!  Tanoshimu!

fkFal73hMpaT_HwipzC42A.text: I've been eating ramen in Las Vegas for probably 4-5 years. 31QKaw9hRCeFCfjVXbO-6Q.text: This place is very good! We were here on a Tuesday afternoon and it wasn't busy. Seated right away and our server was very attentive and kind. I ordered the tonkotsu and my boyfriend ordered the shoyu with Entry Level spicy. We also ordered karaage on the side. The food came in a timely manner, broth was still hot. My boyfriend enjoyed the spiciness of the challenge level available on their menu. The habanero paste is housemade and they also add ghost pepper powder to kick it up a notch. For me, the charsiu didn't have much flavor. But the broth was pretty good, not too salty. The karaage was piping hot and crispy - delicious! Overall, I enjoyed it and would definitely recommend!

UAUNh3ND8mfUKLVcz05MaQ.text: Hubby and I have tried many ramen places in town and this is our consistent favorite. We like spicy, SPICY food and this ramen shop has the absolute spiciest we have tried! They make their own spicy paste from ghost peppers and habaneros. Service is always great and we keep coming back.

e9MjBaBg-hv6eDxh3q6fgg.text: Wow! This ramen place was good! I've had always pass by this place and so glad I finally tried it. They let you pick your spice levels and let me tell you... the spice levels are no joke. I consider myself as a person that can handle spicy and I was shockingly surprise of how spicy it was. If you can not handle spicy, I would steer you from getting any spice levels that contain ghost peppers. Besides that, the broth and noodles are rich in flavors. Portion size is very filling and not pricey compared to the other ramen places around.   The place was clean and service was welcoming right when we walked in to be seated. I would definitely add this place to one of my top ramen shops and I highly recommend you give this place a try.

owzFGKGKm-v1DSxRgeQhaQ.text: I tried two other ramen places in Vegas's Asian district and decided to give Ramen Tatsu a try. The reviews on Yelp were promising and the menu had great prices for their ramen bowls. I had a very positive dining experience and will be going back.  Food 5/5: The noodles were the thick type which I love and the texture was perfect for me, cooked al dente. I tried the Tonkotsu and Tsukemen ramen. Both were great. The Tsukemen had a strong dashi-fish flavor to it, while the Tonkotsu was just pork-flavored. The egg was marinated and perfectly cooked soft-boiled. The charsiu was tender with a nice smoky taste.   Atmosphere/Vibe 4/5:  Cute and cozy interior with Japanese paraphernalia on shelves and art hung on the walls.  I came on a weekday late evening and there was no wait.    Price 5/5: The prices were $3-4 lower per bowl compared to many of the ramen places I've been to. I don't know why that is, but I'm not complaining.   Service/Cleanliness 5/5: The service was very attentive and our food was served quickly. Tables and restaurant were very clean and inviting.   Tip: I experience busy parking lots, parking problems and long waits when I go to ramen places during peak hours. It was only slightly later around 7 PM when I arrived at Ramen Tatsu, and there was plenty of parking and open tables.

D8mXr0QsFRDV8xiRKKcOaQ.text: We found the Ramen Tatsu through Google Maps when we were in Las Vegas and had a sudden craving for hot soup.   We took the fifteen-minute drive over and while the parking lot was packed, it didn't take long before we found a spot!  When we entered the atmosphere was nice and cozy, with small wooden toy houses lining the walls.  The traditional Japanese decorations made it homier.  We were seated quickly seeing that there were only two groups of people and looked through the menus.  We ordered three miso ramens and a Tonkatsu, along with two order of fried rice.  The order came in less than 15 minutes and the components in the bowls were plentiful and all complimented on our taste buds!

1sbjhHOz68WJHDEiJxQhIA.text: Writing this review to simply warn any sane human being from trying the level 1 spicy... I can't believe there's still 2 more levels after this. I am not one to shy away from spicy, as I love the pain spicy food gives me. But let me tell you... their level 1 has got to be the top 3 spiciest things I have ever eaten in my life. I have tried the Last Dab Reduxx from hot ones (2,000,000 scoville units) and that was not as bad as the level 1 ramen at this place... holy crap. I still finished it though because despite it feeling like I was eating cut co knives, it was still very delicious. My waiter was extremely nice and friendly as well.

rFboAt7nZJI15FgMQIhxdQ.text: Mood-  dinner   Upon entering was greeted with great customer service. Was ushered to sit wherever as the rush had not come in yet. Given menus and our server brought over napkins and cutlery.  Opted for the Miso, Chasiu, and Gyoza. Nothing disappointed at all. The food was all brought out relatively quick. The portion for the Miso was nice.   Interior is several tables, and wall booth style with accommodating table and chairs. Interior was very clean.   It does get very busy in here. But it is worth it. Everyone was very friendly and personable. Honestly I love great customer service.   Would def recommend- pricing is reasonable  Location is Spring mountain/ Jones- ample parking, if your there at the right time. It gets pretty congested in this parking lot.

We order gyoza (pot stickers) for our appetizer, spicy miso for our main course no sprouts with extra corn and an egg and when I'm really hungry I add extra noodles! fNsa6Ky2kZrTpcr93XIwhA.text: I went out on a limb and strayed from the mighty 2 Vegas ramen shops and tried Ramen Tatsu.  I'm so glad I did!  Great service, no wait at dinner time, and really solid ramen offerings.  I wanted to try the tsukemen, but when I ordered, they warned me that it smells very fishy.  My husband has an awful aversion to fish (long story), so I decided to avoid the potential disaster and ordered the miso ramen instead.  Husband ordered the tonkotsu.  We started on a happy hour pitcher of Asahi ($16), drinking out of strangely small glasses while we waited.  Tonkotsu Ramen Broth: Creamy and excellent. Noodles: Thin, but not quite right.  Not firm enough. Chashu: delicious!  Very flavorful. Egg: Standard, well cooked.  Miso Ramen Broth (pork/chicken blend): Extremely flavorful!  I could not taste any miso flavor as the broth was on the garlicky side, but still delicious. Noodles: Thick, yellow wavy.  Great!  They were like the chewy noodles typically served with tsukemen. Chashu and egg as above.  Overall, Tatsu is a solid choice for ramen in Vegas.  Although 5* ramen reviews from this ramen snob are hard to come by, I'd say Tatsu might be my favorite in town (so far).

rsx4_vD_V2RgomUR-rcSUw.text: Came here to get the deluxe ramen. Honestly, it wasn't anything special. Soup wasn't super rich, noodles weren't really that tasty. The pork chasu were pretty tasty, but that was it.  I'd pass on this place as there's just too many better options.

YAi_nCzyj1MeAN-NXFua_w.text: Visiting here for EDC week and was craving a hot bowl of soup on a random cold day. I actually came with the intentions of going to another restaurant in the plaza, but the wait was too long. I saw the good reviews on Yelp from this restaurant so I figured why not give it a shot!  My group of 7 ordered a variety of ramen. I personally had the tonkotsu because I like the thinner noodles. For appetizers, we tried the takoyaki and katsu. I loved the takoyaki! It was cooked fresh and served to our table in minutes. As far as ramen goes, the serving size is pretty big. A few people from our table ordered extra noodles and ended up giving a whole bowl to the table next to us because we were so full LOL. I would only recommend ordering extra if you're really hungry. The ramen was delicious, filling, savory, and everything I was looking for on this cold day.   I wish we had a place this good back home, because overall, I was very satisfied with my experience.

7V9m2Kcohi1PUjxntes_Gg.text: The food here is to is so damn good. I always get the veggie ramen with a side of kimchi(which is some of the best kimchi I've ever tried). If you looking for awesome vegetarian/vegan ramen this is the best spot. The server can be hit or miss, but besides that awesome place! I always come back here.

FGar05EdSpwGUYrPq7_wsQ.text: I decided last minute to try this place out which meant I had ZERO idea what I wanted but they were open and I had time to kill so I gave this spot a try and I am glad I did .  When I entered Nanako greeted me right away and let me choose where I wanted to sit . I opted for a booth towards the back of the restaurant . She was my server and promptly got me water while I checked out the menu .  After she brought my water I just asked point blank what is your favorite thing and she was glad to help .  So I went with her pick of the Miso Soup and just request to make it spicy since it comes with her favorite type of toppings which includes yummy corn and bean sprouts and a variety of things plus pork belly . I went with the spicy heat level but they have a varying scale so you could even do challenges with friends here but I wanted to feel my face when I left so I went spicy .  Overall I loved this place from the decor to the service and the flavor and taste . I look forward to coming back with friends so I can try more stuff . I legit got soooo full but it was so yummy

E9KDQHgf34VTxne2vuyw3g.text: I came here on Christmas Day around 11:30am and our party of 9 was seated right away. It quickly filled up by noon.  We got the edamame and fried oyster appetizer for the table. The edamame lacked in flavor and salt. It was also dry and hard. The fried oyster had a strong oyster flavor and little too fried for my taste.   I got the Karaage appetizer and it was juicy and had a good amount of seasoning. The Tsukemen had a perfectly cooked egg. It was a cold dish with the broth on the side. Our table liked the Tonkatsu the best.    Overall a pretty standard ramen restaurant. The service was quick and the servers were friendly.

k5oN_88UTIzAO-T_PR-X9A.text: The tsukemen noodle was too fishy for my liking. I know the original tsukemen noodles from Japan are fishy but I can't be too angry considering on the menu it did say fish broth. I prefer my tuskemen noodles with a perfect balance of sweet, fishy, brothy but possibly other people may like the super Fishy taste. I know from experience that tsukemen is different for everyone so that is why I am not giving them a 1 star review. Service was good from this place.

J_KOqlFHOS5DO__Tx9-zvA.text: I love this place. along with all of my family and friends. this is our go to place. Love the music. Love the vibe. its so nicely decorated as well. the owners are awesome! love ramen tatsu!

jUJtaA2chGuyK34J_5ORIQ.text: I was here after it opened and it was great. The noodles were some of the best I'd had (thin like pho noodles but ramen recipe). Today it was garbage. The noodles are just average and the chashu had a funny taste. I won't be back.

AKxVd4wurvXV9zybkwLZag.text: Was lucky enough to try this gem on their opening day.  By far the best Ramen I have had to date and the staff is great.  Very clean and ramen is always delicious.  I sometimes even order extra noodles because I just can't get enough.

m_xDwZkHLBrmPhUsaPaCBg.text: Stopped by here twice and wasn't necessarily wowed. The first time I ordered tonkotsu ramen and bf ordered spicy miso ramen. While he enjoyed his meal, I thought mine had much to be desired. The chashu was a bit chewy, tough, and lacked flavor, and while the tonkotsu broth appeared creamy, it didn't really taste rich. It was somewhat reminiscent of Anime Ramen's tonkotsu and thats no compliment. The thin noodles and egg were fine, nothing bad to say.  The second time we visited, we both ordered plain miso ramen. The broth was very tangy and tasted rather thin. The thicker curlier noodles served with it were harder (not cooked long enough?) than I would've enjoyed. The chashu, again, was disappointing.   The service was good - it was just two waiters standing towards the back and watching the second anyone needed anything, seeing as how they recently opened, so I feel a bit bad giving them three stars. I think they'll get steady business regardless, however, since they're in a strip mall that also has that karaoke place and Cue D's.

JixCKjrBEmFnnLZu68DInw.text: Kind of cheesy on the inside. And Ramen is very bland. Karrage chicken appetizer was not good. Gave them 3 tries, just no flavor....... :o

ARgapU6qjxkwQ7zl0KoN7w.text: My wife(Japanese)  wanted to get some ramen and we remembered a review in the newspaper. We decided to give the Ramen Tatsu a try. It is a very simple restaurant and the workers were Japanese. We were very happy to find the ramen was excellent and the price was right. I had the curry and my wife had the special. The broth was rich, the pork tender, and the noodles cooked correctly. We will be back.

va8WNuFZmOOatGF9D5ktTQ.text: I give this place 2 stars because of the service. I came to the restaurant on Sunday at 7pm about peak hours for dinner time, there was only 1 lady serving for whole house and the place is full.  First I ask for highchair and the lady said they don't have any. But I saw the lady bring one highchair to a new client so I told her that we come first and we are waiting for highchair and she said she forgot. After we had our food my daughter has to sit on her knee to eat while we are waiting for highchair. Once the other table with the kid left, I saw 1 highchair available BUT she give that highchair to the new group that walking in the restaurant. My husband walk to that table and said we are waiting for highchair but the server said "Oh! sorry I already gave it to the new table. So the entile meal my daughter has to sit on her knee and on my lap to eat because the stupid server never care about us. My husband soup was cold and service is very slow. Disappointed.

wEfPWQV7-On7liOaP0Zd3Q.text: I ordered the Shoyu ramen. It was delicious.   The noodle texture was just right. It was very clean inside the restaurant. The server had good customer service. I liked the atmosphere and design inside the restaurant. The only thing I really wanted was to have a bit more noodles in my ramen without having to pay extra. Overall a great experience.

qnUUQxOvZOWYKwsETVmwJQ.text: If you like ramen you have to go here and try it. The ramen is excellent. The service is great and the staff is friendly. Every time I visit Las Vegas this is definitely one of my stops!

k3_rEFgH_rYMAzjBRcYesg.text: I'm pretty satisfied with Ramen Tatsu.  Good crispy and flavorful gyozas.  I've had the shoyu ramen and the spicy miso, I've also tried (a spoonful) of the Tonkotsu and Shio.  My favorite was the shoyu, the flavor was there, more subtle not salty.  Noodles are al dente and according to one of the waiters they are fresh made daily some place in California.  If we are to compare to the other Vegas notorious ramen place, I feel Monta's broth has become too diluted and salty for me. But Ramen Tatsu does feel a lot like Monta, if fact the chef seems to be the old one from Monta.  The cut of pork is thicker here and less marbled fat which I like.  Good, very friendly service.  Pleasant space to sit down and enjoy dinner, maybe not so much the style of a fast food bustling traditional Japanese ramen, but I like enjoying my beers while I eat and I don't mind this lack of authenticity.  Also a plus, there's never much of a wait here, but it's a new place.  I'll be coming back to Ramen Tatsu for my ramen fix.

dUa3C0EGT2-PBYTpjNh7mg.text: Tatsu Ramien was an excellent experience. The ambiance reminded me of Ramen Houses in Northern Japan. The staff is friendly, accommodating, and allowed me to knock the dust off of my conversational Japanese.  The ramen was good to include the broth. I agree with most of the other reviews about the with of noodles. Make sure to specify the thickness you desire.  My wife and I found the "wide noodle" described on the menu not to be so "wide."  All of the menu choices for the night was well worth it and was served promptly, still hot, and with the friendlyness that we have grown accustomed to while in Japan.   My wife and I enjoyed the meal with another couple. The total bill was under $70 dollars and we did not skimp on side dishes. We were all satiated, full, and satisfied.  The environment can accommodate both quick meals for singular people as well as groups. I would also feel comfortable taking my children to the restaurant.  Tatsu gets our "enthusiastic thums up."  Go check it out for yourselves!

ulkSBKRw68MAii_Lu6u2yA.text: I have been craving their tsukemen.  I have been to Monta and Sora in the last 4 weeks and I needed something different.  When I went there about a month ago, it was closed for renovation of some sort.  As it just opened not very long ago, I'm not sure what they needed to do.    When I arrived today, it didn't look much different at all, so I'm not sure why they've been closed, but anyway, I was stunned to find out that tsukemen has been eliminated from the menu.  As I believe that Monta and Fukumi are the places to go for tonkotsu, sora for miso, and tatsu for tsukemen, it was quite disappointing.    Anyway, I had tonkotsu as I just had monta last week and wanted to compare the two.    Let me just say that their ramen is good, but it's not the TYPE of tonkotsu that I like.  If you like shinsengumi in L.A., you will like their version of tonkotsu, but I personally favor more thicker, heavy tonkotsu flavor that you see in Monta or Daikokuya.    You do see variation in the tonkotsu flavor in Japan, and I'm not going to say that one is better than the other, but it comes down more to personal preference and this isn't the type of tonkotsu that I like, hence I'd say 3.5 stars.    I wonder if there wasn't enough demand for tsukemen to keep it on the menu?  but it is certainly a disappointment for me.

1bt3x950s_STGsPx9B7icw.text: Went a week night several weeks ago with kids. They were able to accommodate a table for 6 with no problem. Fantastic assortment of food...just check out their menu! High quality ramen with awesome flavors at a very reasonable price. Spotted this place by chance and decided to check it out.  I plan to return as often as I can and will recommend this place for all who seek homestyle Japanese ramen and related dishes. Look out Monta and Jinya, these guys are your respectable competition.

FLuAURkgO2I4FsFSwq1mjw.text: Ordered the Tonkatsu Ramen (only one with thin noodles), Gyoza, Karaage with a side salad. All good flavors and very attentive food service! Yes I have tried a lot of other Ramen places I won't mention because they are all good in their own right. Easily one of the best Ramen and prices very competitive especially in happy hour (3-6). Very clean restaurant and nicer than most, good food with very good table manners and service will have my recommendations anytime.

mh0l5Mj0DLBc1F9NCgy8zQ.text: Everytime we are in Vegas Ramen Tatsu ends up being our next day hang over meal.
